1910 Los Angeles CA
Carolyn Wolcott 54 b. PA own income
Helen Wolcott 17 b. CO legal stenographer
Annie S Dornberg 31 roomer ,garment fitter




Robert D. Wolcott (1888-1947), was my mother's grandfather. We believe that his parents were William Merwin Wolcott (b. 1848) and his wife Caroline Delange (b. 1857). They were married 16 Apr 1881 but I do not know where. A 1900 Federal Census Report puts Robert D. Wolcott as the son to a Caroline B Wolcott along with a sibling Helen D S Wolcott (his sister). It also states that their father was born in Ohio. Unfortunately, there is no mention of William Merwin Wolcott in this or any census report. The same census report lists Caroline B. Wolcott as a widow so if William Merwin Wolcott was their father then he passed before 1900. Helen Wolcott later went on to be a Broadway actress and stared in a few "talkies", which is what they called movies when they first came out with sound. Robert Wolcott later married Amy Glezen on 5 Nov 1919 and they had three children; Robert G. Wolcott (My mother's father) 1920-1955, Helen B. Wolcott (living) and Donna Jane Wolcott (living).
m. 1872 Sarah Harding "Sallie" Crothers, b. 20 AUG 1848 , d. 5 JAN 1873 .
(8) William Merwin Wolcott8 (Christopher Parsons Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 DEC 1849 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. ABT 1890 .
NotesWILLIAM attended college. He apparently died shortly after his second marriage when his wife is listed as a widow.

1900 Denver CO:
Caroline D Wolcott 43, b. PA Oct 1856, bakery
Robert D Wolcott 12, b. CO Feb 1888
Helen D S Wolcott 7, b. Co Sept 1892

1908 Denver CO
Mrs. Caroline D. Wolcott
Miss Helen S. Wolcott, student
Robert D.Wolcott, meter reader

1910 Los Angeles CA
Carolyn Wolcott 54 b. PA own income
Helen Wolcott 17 b. CO legal stenographer
Annie S Dornberg 31 roomer ,garment fitter




Robert D. Wolcott (1888-1947), was my mother's grandfather. We believe that his parents were William Merwin Wolcott (b. 1848) and his wife Caroline Delange (b. 1857). They were married 16 Apr 1881 but I do not know where. A 1900 Federal Census Report puts Robert D. Wolcott as the son to a Caroline B Wolcott along with a sibling Helen D S Wolcott (his sister). It also states that their father was born in Ohio. Unfortunately, there is no mention of William Merwin Wolcott in this or any census report. The same census report lists Caroline B. Wolcott as a widow so if William Merwin Wolcott was their father then he passed before 1900. Helen Wolcott later went on to be a Broadway actress and stared in a few "talkies", which is what they called movies when they first came out with sound. Robert Wolcott later married Amy Glezen on 5 Nov 1919 and they had three children; Robert G. Wolcott (My mother's father) 1920-1955, Helen B. Wolcott (living) and Donna Jane Wolcott (living).
m. 16 APR 1881 Caroline Delange, b. 4 OCT 1856 Pittsburgh, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania, d. .
Spouse NotesCAROLINE was at Pittsburg, Pennsylvania, in 1860 with her mother Louisa Delange 38, born Massachusetts, Julia 7, Caroline 4, and Frank E. 2, all born Pennsylvania. Caroline's granddaughter, Donna, said she adopted Robert when a friend who worked as a maid in a wealthy family asked her to do so, saying that a daughter of that family got pregnant and her parents opposed marriage. She also said Caroline later adopted Helen. Caroline D. Wolcott, widow, working in a bakery, was at Denver, Colorado, in 1900, with Robert D. and Helen D. S. Wolcott. The census record says she and her father were born in Pennsylvania, and her mother in Massachusetts, and her childrens father was born in Ohio. In 1910 Caroline Wolcott, 59, self and father born Pennsylvania, mother born Massachusetts, was at Los Angeles with "own income", with daughter Helen Wolcott, self and father born Colorado, stenographer.
(8) Darwin Stanton Wolcott8 (Christopher Parsons Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 JUL 1851 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 15 FEB 1927 Sewickley, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesDARWIN attended Kenyon College, and was was at College, Ohio, in 1870. He was employed by the United States Coast Survey as an emgineer for 5 or 6 years, and then worked for the Patent Office in Washington D. C.. He moved to Pittsburg in 1883 and in partnership with George H. Christy, established a law office. He was an attorney at Pittsburg in the 1890s and assisted Reginald Fessening in registering patents on his inventions for radio broadcasting. He helped Fessening find financial backers for setting up the National Electric Signaling Co. and was one of the principal shareholders in the company. The company sent the first two-way wireless communication across the Atlantic and produced the first radio broadcast program in 1906. In 1910 he established his own practice. He settled at Sedgewickley, where he was a member of the Episcopal Church.

1910 Sewickley PA:
Darwin S Wolcott 54, b. OH widower, lawyer, patent attorney
Darwin S Wolcott Jr 32. b. Dist of Columbia, office mgr., steel works
Catherine R Wolcott 28, b. Dist. of Columbia
Christopher P Wolcott 26, b. Dist of Columbia, Supt. Tin mill
Mary L Wolcott 21, b. PA
Robert W Wolcott 17, b. PA
Evelyn M Wolcott 15, b. PA
Kate Stepanczk 19, servant
m. 23 JUL 1876 Winchester, Frederick Co., Virginia, Evelyn Brent Reily, b. 27 OCT 1856 Winchester, Frederick Co., Virginia, d. JUN 1902 .
Spouse NotesEVELYN was moved from Union Cemetery, Steubenville, to Sewickley 9 April 1927, to lie beside her husband.
(7) Samuel Merwin Wolcott7 (Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 JUN 1822 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 3 AUG 1848 .
(7) Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott7 (Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 FEB 1824 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 11 MAY 1868 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
NotesHENRY P. Wolcott of Steubenville, Ohio, attended the Western Reserve College 1840-41. He was a woolen manufacturer at Steubenville, Ohio, in 1850. He was at Steubenville, Ohio, in 1860, with Sarah, Susan, Harry, Laura, Jessie, and Carrie. Jessie Wolcott Cool is married inthe same cemetery lot.
m. 26 JAN 1847 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, Sarah Ann Allen, b. 22 FEB 1827 Ravenna, Portage Co., Ohio, d. 1904 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesSARAH was at Steubebville, Ohio, in 1870, with Laura, Jessie, and Carrie. She and her children, Jesse and Carrie, were living at Steubenville in 1880. In 1900 she lived with her daughter, Laura. Ann and Thomas Allen, possibly her parents, are buried in the same cemetery lot.
6 children: Susan Maria, Henry Frederick, Laura Elizabeth, David Jesse "Jesse", Caroline Andrews "Carrie", Henry Allen.
(8) Susan Maria Wolcott8 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 JUL 1848 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 23 APR 1918 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesSUSAN was visiting her second husband, who was a resident in the Chicago Home for Insurables since 1916, when she was injured in an fatal elevator accident.
m. 17 NOV 1868 , Jefferson Co., Ohio, Ryan Welsh Allison, b. 19 AUG 1844 , d. 27 NOV 1877 .
(8) Susan Maria Wolcott8 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 JUL 1848 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 23 APR 1918 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesSUSAN was visiting her second husband, who was a resident in the Chicago Home for Insurables since 1916, when she was injured in an fatal elevator accident.
m. 1 MAR 1892 Charles Pierson Chesebro, b. 11 JUL 1845 Canandaigua, Ontario Co., New York, d. Saint Louis, Saint Louis Co., Missouri.
Spouse NotesCHARLES served in the Union Army. He was an accountant for the Wabash Railroad at St. Louis, Missouri.
(8) Henry Frederick Wolcott8 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 APR 1851 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 1909 .
NotesHenry F. Wolcott, age 29, born in Ohio, was a photographer at Petoskey, Michigan, in 1880.
m. 1 DEC 1872 Mary Hoxworth, b. SEP 1849 , d. .
(8) Laura Elizabeth Wolcott8 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 MAY 1854 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 24 NOV 1924 Toledo, Lucas Co., Ohio.
NotesLAURA was a school teacher at Steubenville in 1872. She was a widow at Steubenville in 1910, living with son Allyn W. Matlack, who worked in an iron mill.

the
death of Mrs. Laura W. Matlack,
former well known nnd highly
esteemed resident of this city,
which occurred at a Toledo hospital
early this morning. Mrs
Matlack underwent a surgical operation
Sunday evening, and was
improving nicely when pneumonia
set in, death resulting after only
a few short hours of suffering.
The remains will arrive in this
o'clock, with Father Sidener officiating.
Interment will take
place in tho Union cemetery.
Mrs Matlack was born and
raised in Steubenvllle, a member
of one of the oldest and most
highly esteemed familles in the
valley. She was educated in the
public schools of the city and was
a graduate of the Steubenvllle
high school. She was the daughter
of the late Henry nnd Sarah
Allen Wolcott, and the wife of the
late David W. Matlack, Who preceded
her in death in 1907. She
was a member of the Episcopal
Church from early girlhood, and
an active worker in all religious
matters. For the past eight
years She has been making her
home with grandchildren in Toledo.
Surviving the loss of loving
and devoted mother are two children,
Harry W., of Grinnell, Iowa, and A. Wolcott of this city. One daughter, Helen, , with whose
chiidren, Mrs. Matlack has been
making her home, preceded her in
death. Two sisters, Mrs; J . H;
Tlmberlake of this, city and Mrs,
Jessie W. Cook Of Spokane,
Wash., also survive.
m. 12 JUL 1873 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, David W. Matlack, b. 25 AUG 1848 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 27 APR 1907 .
Spouse NotesDAVID was a school teacher at Steubenville, Ohio, in 1850-1900. In 1895 he was elected president of the Eastern Ohio Teacher's Assocoation.
(8) David Jesse "Jesse" Wolcott8 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 NOV 1856 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. ABT 1935 .
(8) Caroline Andrews "Carrie" Wolcott8 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 JUN 1859 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 26 DEC 1943 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
NotesCARRIE was a school teacher at Steubenville in 1880 and 1885, and was living there in 1914.Philip Wolcott Timberlake and Richard Henry Timberlake of Steubenville attended the 1911 Wolcott reunion and were probably her sons. Also attending from Steubenville was Rev. William Martin Sidener, possibly another relative.
m. 2 FEB 1887 Gambier, Knox Co., Ohio, John Henry Timberlake, b. 21 OCT 1856 Cincinnati, Hamilton Co., Ohio, d. 27 SEP 1949 Gambier, Knox Co., Ohio.
(8) Henry Allen Wolcott8 (Henry Philip "Harry" Wolcott7, Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 APR 1866 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio, d. 15 AUG 1866 .

(7) Susan Maria Wolcott7 (Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 AUG 1827 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 5 OCT 1833 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
(7) Caroline Matilda Wolcott7 (Christopher Columbus Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 MAY 1829 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. MAR 1910 .
NotesCAROLINE M. Wolcott was a student at the Steubenville Academy 1836-7 and 1844-6, grauating in 1846.

(8) Warren Ward Marshall8 (Oliver Wolcott Marshall7, Elizabeth Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 JAN 1868 Northfield-Macedonia Cemetery, Northfield, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 30 MAY 1928 New Britain, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesWARREN was an experimental engineer, and an inventor of small household appliances. His daughter Ruth gave his middle name as Ward.
m. 6 OCT 1891 New Britain, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Nellie Ruth Penfield, b. 8 OCT 1867 New Britain, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. FEB 1956 Worcester, Worcester Co., Massachusetts.
(7) James Christopher Marshall7 (Elizabeth Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 18 SEP 1818 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 11 JAN 1888 .
(7) John Randolph Marshall7 (Elizabeth Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 JUL 1822 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 11 JUL 1891 Dublin, Franklin Co., Ohio.
NotesJOHN was one of the first Doctors in Dublin, Ohio. He served as an officer in the Mexican War in 1846, in Company I, 3rd Regiment, Ohio Volunteer Infantry Regt. He was an Ohio state representative, and a contributor to the Columbus Record. He is said to have discovered a cure for black diptheria and for cholera. In 1998 his doctors office was still standing.
m. 29 AUG 1852 Worthington, Franklin Co., Ohio, Louise Marie Lusk, b. 18 AUG 1832 Worthington, Franklin Co., Ohio, d. 11 JUN 1873 Dublin, Franklin Co., Ohio.
8 children: Mary Amanda, Julia Ellen, Lucy Ann, John Warren, Ida, Oliver Wolcott, Thurman Franklin, Asa Harris.

(7) Lucy Ann Marshall7 (Elizabeth Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 NOV 1827 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1903 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 25 NOV 1850 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Ellsworth Newberry Phelps, b. 9 FEB 1826 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. JAN 1913 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesELLSWORTH enlisted in Co. A, 22nd Connecticut Inf. Regt. in 1862, and was elected Captain of the company. He recruited 130 men and was appointed Lt. Col. of the Regt. He was a Whig and later a Republican, an Episcopalian, justice of the peace, and grand juror. He was assistant civil engineer on the Connecticut River, surveying much of Hartford County. He also had a farm.
2 children: Samuel Ellsworth, Annie Marshall.
(8) Samuel Ellsworth Phelps8 (Lucy Ann Marshall7, Elizabeth Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 JUN 1852 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesSAMUEL was elected Town Clerk of Windsor 5 October 1885. He was the postmaster at Windsor.
m. 28 MAR 1871 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Adella J. Filley, b. 9 MAY 1853 , d. .
(8) Annie Marshall Phelps8 (Lucy Ann Marshall7, Elizabeth Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 JAN 1858 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesANNIE was a member of the Wolcott Society 1909-17, residing at Hartford, Connecticut.
m. 29 OCT 1887 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Hugh Harbison, b. , d. .
(6) Philip Wolcott6 (Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 MAY 1794 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 15 DEC 1850 Steubenville, Jefferson Co., Ohio.
m. 10 JUL 1817 Emilia "Emily" Marshall, b. 18 JUL 1794 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 4 OCT 1881 .
1 children: Frances.
(7) Frances Wolcott7 (Philip Wolcott6, Christopher Drake Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 APR 1818 , d. .
m. 1839 , Hartford Co., Connecticut, Ralph Ralston, b. 1818 , Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
(5) Christopher Drake Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 OCT 1754 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 APR 1821 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesCHRISTOPHER studied medicine with his father. He was a surgeon's mate in Col. Erastus Wolcott's regiment from December 1775 to January 1781 during the Revolutionary War. He was granted land at Enosburg, Franklin County, New Hampshire, for his military service. He was a physician at Windsor, Connecticut, one of the founders of the Hartford County Medical Society, and served as a Representative to the General Assembly. He lived in his father's house after his father's death. In 1790 he was at Windsor with a family of 3 males over 16, 2 males under 16, and 5 females.
m. 26 SEP 1806 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Amy Gillett, b. 30 JUL 1770 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 JUL 1835 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Mary Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 AUG 1756 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .

2 children: Mary, Sophia.

(7) Sophia Ellen Hackley7 (Sophia Griswold6, Mary Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 JUL 1819 ,, New York, d. 27 AUG 1904 ,, New York.
m. 30 AUG 1843 Utica, Oneida Co., New York, David Parish Barhydt, b. 16 APR 1816 Ogdensburg, St. Lawrence Co., New York, d. 13 FEB 1908 New York City, New York.
1 children: Kate Wolcott.
(8) Kate Wolcott Barhydt8 (Sophia Ellen Hackley7, Sophia Griswold6, Mary Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 MAR 1848 , d. 1913 .
Notes KATE was Wolcott Society vice-president for New York in 1909-10, residing at Mt. Vernon New York. After her death, her husband continued to be a member.
m. 12 APR 1883 Herman Drisler, b. 1857 ,, New York, d. .
Spouse NotesHERMAN Drisler, of Mt. Vernon, New York, was a member of the Wolcott Society 1909-17. He was on the Society finance committee in 1909. He is probably the Herman Drisler, age 3, born New York, who was with Elizabeth Drisler 40, born New York, at Northampton, New Jersey, in 1860. In 1880 he was a lawyer at New York City, age 23, living with his father, Henry Drisler, a professor.
(5) Alexander Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 SEP 1758 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 26 JUN 1828 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale College in 1778 and practiced law in Windsor, where he was a Representative to the General Assembly for five sessions, 1796-1801. He was a member of the Susquehanna Land Company in 1786. He had warrant of 50,000 acres on south side of Powell's Muntain on Guest's River, and 100,000 acres on the west bank of Tottery Creek in 1795. In 1796 he sold a grant of 100,000 acres on the East Branch of the Big Sandy River in Russell Co., Virginia, to Ebenezer Fitch Bissell. In 1799 he held 12,500 acres of land in Grayson Co., Virginia. His land holding claims were disputed due to disagreements between Virginia and Kentucky over their borders, and "Wolcotters" became a term for people with dubious land claims. Alexander Smyth of Wythe Co., Virginia, contracted with Alexander Wolcott of Connecticut to survey 850,000 acres of land. An 1800 deed conveyed 1,034 acres of land from Alexander Smyth to Alexander Wolcott of Windsor, Connecticut, for 434 dollars. Alexander was at Middleton, Connecticut in 1800, were he was a Justice of the Peace. He was Collector of Customs for Middletown there from 1801 until his death in 1828, when he was succeeded by his eldest son. He was one of the early manufacturers of woolen cloth in this country. Alexander was one of the leaders of the Republican Party of Connecticut. He was nominated for the U.S. Supreme Court by President Madison in 1810, but the nomination failed to get the approval of the Senate for political reasons, 24 to 9. It was said "But he was widely unpopular as revenue collectors tend to be". He was a member of the State Constitutional Convention in 1818.
m. 22 SEP 1785 West Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, Frances Burbank, b. 1765 Springfield, Hampshire, after 1812 Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 17 JAN 1800 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
4 children: Frances, Henry, Alexander, Mary Ann.
(6) Frances Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 AUG 1786 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. AFT 1835 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
m. 2 MAR 1804 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, Thomas Homans, b. ABT 1780 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1805 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
1 children: Frances.
(7) Frances Homans7 (Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1804 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. ABT 1865 .
(6) Frances Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 AUG 1786 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. AFT 1835 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
m. 5 JAN 1806 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, Arthur William Magill, b. 3 AUG 1783 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1855 Ottawa, LaSalle Co., Illinois.
7 children: Juliette Augusta, William A., Mary Ann Wolcott, Arthur, Henry Wolcott, Alexander Wolcot, Julian.
(7) Juliette Augusta Magill7 (Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 SEP 1806 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 17 SEP 1870 Amagansett, Suffolk Co., New York.
NotesJULIETTE was called "Chicago's First Author". She attended Emma Willard's Scholl at Troy, New York, and her uncle, Alexander Wolcott, taught her Latin and other languages. She accompanied her husband into the wilderness of Wisconsin, Michigan, and Illinois. Her best known book, published in 1856, was entitled "Waubun, the Early Days in the Northwest". It was a story of her experiences living in the wilderness from 1830 to 1833.
m. 9 AUG 1827 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York, John Harris Kinzie, b. 7 JUL 1803 Sandwich,, Canada, d. 21 JUN 1865 Pittsburgh, Allegheny Co., Pennsylvania.
Spouse NotesJOHN came with his father to what is now Chicago, in 1803. They were among the first settlers there. John moved to Detroit, Michiigan in 1816, and was appointed Indian Agent for the Winnebagos there in 1828. From 1830 to 1833, he travelled throught Wisconsin, Michigan, and Illinois, distributing blankets, cloth, guns, Kettles, traps, and other things to the Indians as a representative of the U.S. government. He signed as a witness to a treaty between the U. S. government and the Chippewa Indian Nation in 1833, and is listed in an attachment to the treaty as rustee for money owed under the treaty to Jean Bt. Miranda, Jane Miranda, Rosetta Miranda, and Thomas Miranda, and for Josett Ouilmot. In another attachment to the treaty, John H. Kinzie and Ellen M. Wolcott were named as owed $5,000 each. On returning to Chicago in 1834, he became President of the Board of Trustees of the village. He was appointed Registrar of Public Lands at Chicago in 1841, and Paymaster of the U.S. Army in 1861. In 1865 he was brevetted Lt. Colonel in the U.S. Army. He built the First Episcopal Church in Chicago.
7 children: Eleanor Lytle "Nellie", Wolcott, John Harris, Arthur, Julian, Frank, George.
(8) Eleanor Lytle "Nellie" Kinzie8 (Juliette Augusta Magill7, Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1835 Fort Dearborn, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 22 FEB 1917 Amagansett, Suffolk Co., New York.
NotesEleanor was the first white child born in Chicago.
m. 21 DEC 1857 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, William Washington Gordon, b. 1834 Savannah, Chatham Co., Georgia, d. 11 SEP 1912 Savannah, Chatham Co., Georgia.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM graduated from Yale University and was a cotton merchant in Savannah, Georgia. He was a Lieutenant in the Confederate Army during the Civil War. He lost everything in the war. After the war he served in the Georgia State Cavalry. He was appointed Brigadier General in 1898 in the Spanish American War, and was Commissioner to supervise the evacuation of the Spanish from Puerto Rico.
(8) Wolcott Kinzie8 (Juliette Augusta Magill7, Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1839 Fishkill, Dutchess Co., New York, d. 1845 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
(8) John Harris Kinzie8 (Juliette Augusta Magill7, Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1841 Fort Dearborn, Cook Co., Illinois, d. ABT 1864 .
(8) Arthur Kinzie8 (Juliette Augusta Magill7, Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1842 Fort Dearborn, Cook Co., Illinois, d. ABT 1900 .
(8) Julian Kinzie8 (Juliette Augusta Magill7, Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1843 Fort Dearborn, Cook Co., Illinois, d. ABT 1890 .
(8) Frank Kinzie8 (Juliette Augusta Magill7, Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1844 Fort Dearborn, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 1850 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.

(7) William A. Magill7 (Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 JUN 1808 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 18 FEB 1835 Ottawa, LaSalle Co., Illinois.

(7) Arthur Magill7 (Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 DEC 1813 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 18 SEP 1833 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
(7) Henry Wolcott Magill7 (Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 NOV 1815 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1818 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
(7) Alexander Wolcot Magill7 (Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 OCT 1817 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. JUL 1867 Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.
(7) Julian Magill7 (Frances Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 FEB 1822 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. AFT 1850 .
m. ABT 1845 Laura Almyra Rumsey, b. ABT 1825 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. AFT 1845 .
(6) Henry Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 MAR 1788 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 5 APR 1846 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesHENRY was a physician. He was a Justice of the Peace and was appointed Collector of the Port at Middleton in 1828. In 1833, he moved to Chicago, Illinois, where he practiced medicine. Henry Wolcott had a private boarding house at Wolcott and Kinzie Streets in Chicago, in 1839.
m. 6 NOV 1813 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, Mary Almira Starr, b. 2 MAR 1795 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 30 MAR 1870 .
9 children: Alexander, Henry Huntington, Caroline Starr, Edward, Frances Burbank, Ellen, Almira, Emma, Juliette.
(7) Alexander Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 OCT 1814 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 11 AUG 1884 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesALEXANDER may have been the Alex Walcott, age 35, who was an engineer at Yuba City, California, in 1850. He was Cook County Surveyor in 1868. He was a surveyor at Chicago, Ilinois, in 1880.
m. 25 DEC 1845 , Dupage Co., Illinois, Mary A. Spaulding, b. 1817 ,, Massachusetts, d. 28 AUG 1909 , Cook Co., Illinois.
3 children: Henry Alexander, Charles, Cecilia.
(8) Henry Alexander Wolcott8 (Alexander Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1862 Chicago Heights, Cook Co., Illinois, d. .
NotesHENRY A. Wolcott of Illinois was a student at Notre Dame University in 1895-6. He married Mary Darrow.
m. 1 MAY 1882 , Cook Co., Illinois, Mary Elizabeth Darrow, b. 13 DEC 1861 Lowell, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. 9 MAR 1926 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
(8) Charles Wolcott8 (Alexander Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1864 ,, Illinois, d. .
(8) Cecilia Wolcott8 (Alexander Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1865 ,, Illinois, d. .
(7) Henry Huntington Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 AUG 1816 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 28 SEP 1890 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York.
NotesHENRYmoved to Chicago in 1832 with his brother, Alexander. They lived with the family of his cousin, Mrs. John Kinzie. Henry Huntington Wolcott of Racine Co., Wisconsin, purchased 160 acres of government land at Racine Co. in 1843. He was listed as H. H. Wolcott in the 1844 city directory of Chicago, as clerk at Humphries & Winslow's, and residing at the City Hotel, and/or the Henry Wolcott, clerk at the post office and resident at the City Hotel. He was later in the transportation business on the Great Lakes and the Illinois and Michigan Canal. In 1859 returned to the East where he and his childhood friend, Eben Townsend Starr, and others formed the Starr Arms Company at Lowell, Massachusetts. Henry was a major investor and President of the company, which moved to Binghampton, and finally to Yonkers, New York. Henry and Eben Townsend grew up together at Middletown, Connecticut, and shared a great-grandfather, Jehosaphat Starr. They established an armory at Yonkers, New York. Henry held several patents for inventions connected with guns. Their company manufactured arms for the Union Army during the Civil War. In 1860 it accepted a contract for 12,000 pistols, then another 8,000 and 10,000 breech loading carbines.They had armories at Binghampton and Yonkers. After the war, they sold surplus arms to foreign governments. In 1880 Henry was a paper box manufacturer in New York City. Henry's son, Townsend, was named after Eben Starr and was the Executor of Eben's estate in 1899. His obituary said he was survived by his wife, two sons, and a daughter. Research on Henry and Eben Starr is being done by Robin Eichleay, P. O. Box 49297, Los Angeles CA 90049, 612 860-2783
m. 13 OCT 1852 Niagara Falls, Niagara Co., New York, Elizabeth Franklin Townsend, b. 21 NOV 1820 Goshen, Orange Co., New York, d. 10 JUL 1896 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York.
5 children: Elizabeth Mary, Henry, Townsend, Jennie, Juliette.
(8) Elizabeth Mary Wolcott8 (Henry Huntington Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1854 ,, New York, d. 1941 .
(8) Henry Wolcott8 (Henry Huntington Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 OCT 1855 ,, New York, d. 21 JUL 1938 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesHENRY was a merchant in New York City in 1880. In 1932, he donated a memorial window to the Tolland, England, church. The Wolcott Memorial Chapel in St. Paul's Church, Brookline, Massachusetts, was given by his widow in memory of Henry and Elizabeth Wolcott and their descendants, Henry Huntington Wolcott and his wife, Elizabeth Townsend, and their sons, Henry and Huntington, and their daughter, Elizabeth, in 1944. Henry was Rhode Island state vice president of the Wolcott Society before his marriage.
m. 6 FEB 1929 Brookline, Norfolk Co., Massachusetts, Cora Codman, b. 12 JUL 1874 , d. Brookline, Norfolk Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesCORA was the author of "The Codmans of Charlestown and Boston, 1637-1929".
(8) Townsend Wolcott8 (Henry Huntington Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1857 ,, New York, d. 29 APR 1910 New York City, New York.
NotesTOWNSEND was a member and officer of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers. He was one of the authors of "The Electro Magnet", published in 1900. He was Secretary-Treasurer of the Wolcott Society. He created a card index of Wolcott Society members, for which the Society paid him $7 in 1909.
(8) Jennie Wolcott8 (Henry Huntington Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1859 , d. 1863 .
(8) Juliette Wolcott8 (Henry Huntington Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1863 , d. 1864 .
(7) Caroline Starr Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 OCT 1818 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 1901 .
m. 19 JUN 1837 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, Joseph Neree Balestier, b. 1 APR 1814 Martinique, West Indies, d. 1888 Arlington, Bennington Co., Vermont.
Spouse NotesJOSEPH was schooled by his brother's sister-in-law, Harriet Revere, daughter of Paul Revere. He then studied law. In 1835 he moved to Chicago where he practiced law for 7 years. He was a delegate to the convention that nominated Abraham Lincoln for President. In 1842 the Balestiers moved to New York City, where he was senior partner in the law firm, Balestier & Lane. He retired to his home, "Beechwood, in Vermont, where he died.
5 children: Robert Starr, Henry Wolcott, John Augustus, Joseph Neree, Caroline Wolcott.
(8) Robert Starr Balestier8 (Caroline Starr Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 OCT 1838 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 23 NOV 1903 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York.
m. 1865 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York, Mary Holmes , b. 1843 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York, d. 15 JAN 1867 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York.
(8) Robert Starr Balestier8 (Caroline Starr Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 OCT 1838 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 23 NOV 1903 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York.
m. 1868 Unadilla, Otsego Co., New York, Fannie Maria , b. 27 APR 1837 Holmesville, Otsego Co., New York, d. 26 AUG 1915 Los Angeles, Los Angeles Co., California.
Spouse NotesFANNIE was Joseph's sister-in-law, sister of his first wife.
(8) Henry Wolcott Balestier8 (Caroline Starr Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1840 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 23 AUG 1870 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesHENRY was a lawyer and an insurance agent in New York City,
m. 1860 Anna Smith, b. 1838 Rochester, Monroe Co., New York, d. 22 MAR 1919 Brattleboro, Windham Co., Vermont.
(8) John Augustus Balestier8 (Caroline Starr Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 SEP 1842 New York City, New York, d. 5 SEP 1912 New York City, New York.
m. Emily Elliot, b. Of Exeter, Rockingham Co., New Hampshire, d. .
(8) Joseph Neree Balestier8 (Caroline Starr Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 SEP 1845 New York City, New York, d. 19 APR 1909 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
m. 29 JUL 1883 Emma Brown, b. , d. 22 FEB 1923 South Minneapolis,, Minnesota.
(8) Caroline Wolcott Balestier8 (Caroline Starr Wolcott7, Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 FEB 1852 New York City, New York, d. 25 MAR 1855 New York City, New York.
(7) Edward Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 JUL 1821 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. .
NotesEDWARD was a school teacher in Glenn, Montgomery Co., New York. In 1880 he and his wife were living in a hotel at Washington, D.C.
m. 15 JUN 1848 Anna McCracken, b. 1833 ,, Delaware, d. .
(7) Frances Burbank Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 NOV 1823 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. FEB 1841 Leonard Proctor, b. , d. .
(7) Ellen Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 JAN 1828 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 13 FEB 1829 .
(7) Almira Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. JAN 1830 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 16 JAN 1830 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
(7) Emma Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 JUL 1832 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. AUG 1848 .
(7) Juliette Wolcott7 (Henry Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 NOV 1835 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 8 AUG 1836 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
(6) Alexander Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 FEB 1790 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 23 NOV 1830 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale College in 1807. He subsequently studied medicine with Dr. Nathan Smith at Hanover, New Hampshire. He enlisted 25 May 1812 and was commissioned Surgeon's Mate in the U.S. Army, stationed at Ft. Moultrie, South Carolina, and Governors Island. After the war he established himself as a physician at Vincennes, Indiana. Alexander was appointed Indian Agent at Detroit in 1819, and accompanied Gov. Lewis Cass on his exploration of Lake Superior and the Mississippi headwaters in 1820. He was appointed Indian Agent at Chicago in 1820. His residence in Chicago was call "Cobweb Castle", and he lived there until his marriage in 1823. It was the first wedding in Chicago. He was also a Justice of the Peace. In 1830 he purchased for 600 dollars 8 lots in Chicago. His land is now the site of the Marina City Towers complex. His widow inherited his property and deeded these lands to David Hunter. On the 1830 census he is recorded at Fort Dearborn as a family with Alexander 40-50, 1 male 20-30, 1 male 10-15, 1 male 5-10, and 5 females age 60-70, Eleanor 30-40, 20-30, 15-20, 10-15, and 5-10, the elder woman probably his mother-in-law. His will left his property to his wife and his daughter, Mary Ann, his only living child.
m. 20 JUL 1823 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, Eleanor Marion Kinzie, b. DEC 1804 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 1 AUG 1849 Detroit, Wayne Co., Michigan.
Spouse NotesELEANOR was the first white child born in Chicago, Illinois.
3 children: Mary Ann, Ellen Maria, Alexander.
(7) Mary Ann Wolcott7 (Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1825 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 16 JAN 1832 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois.
(7) Ellen Maria Wolcott7 (Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1826 ,, Illinois, d. CHILD .
(7) Alexander Wolcott7 (Alexander Wolcott6, Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1829 ,, Illinois, d. CHILD .
(6) Mary Ann Wolcott6 (Alexander Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 FEB 1792 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 7 SEP 1865 .
(5) Alexander Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 SEP 1758 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 26 JUN 1828 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut.
NotesALEXANDER graduated from Yale College in 1778 and practiced law in Windsor, where he was a Representative to the General Assembly for five sessions, 1796-1801. He was a member of the Susquehanna Land Company in 1786. He had warrant of 50,000 acres on south side of Powell's Muntain on Guest's River, and 100,000 acres on the west bank of Tottery Creek in 1795. In 1796 he sold a grant of 100,000 acres on the East Branch of the Big Sandy River in Russell Co., Virginia, to Ebenezer Fitch Bissell. In 1799 he held 12,500 acres of land in Grayson Co., Virginia. His land holding claims were disputed due to disagreements between Virginia and Kentucky over their borders, and "Wolcotters" became a term for people with dubious land claims. Alexander Smyth of Wythe Co., Virginia, contracted with Alexander Wolcott of Connecticut to survey 850,000 acres of land. An 1800 deed conveyed 1,034 acres of land from Alexander Smyth to Alexander Wolcott of Windsor, Connecticut, for 434 dollars. Alexander was at Middleton, Connecticut in 1800, were he was a Justice of the Peace. He was Collector of Customs for Middletown there from 1801 until his death in 1828, when he was succeeded by his eldest son. He was one of the early manufacturers of woolen cloth in this country. Alexander was one of the leaders of the Republican Party of Connecticut. He was nominated for the U.S. Supreme Court by President Madison in 1810, but the nomination failed to get the approval of the Senate for political reasons, 24 to 9. It was said "But he was widely unpopular as revenue collectors tend to be". He was a member of the State Constitutional Convention in 1818.
m. 7 JUN 1807 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Lucy Waldo, b. 10 AUG 1766 Falmouth, Cumberland Co., Maine, d. 10 SEP 1839 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
(5) Guy Wolcott5 (Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 AUG 1760 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 SEP 1823 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
NotesGUY was at Litchfield Co., Connecticut in 1790, with a family of 2 males under 16, 2 males over 16, and 2 females. He settled at Torrington, Connecticut, in 1783, on a farm a mile and a half west of what became Wolcottville. The name was given the town by popular vote after Guy and Frederick Wolcott built a woolen mill on the Waterbury River there in 1813. Guy was elected deacon of the Torrington church in 1821. The mill ran into financial difficulties, and in 1822 Guy moved to Tallmadge, Ohio, where his eldest son had settled a few years earlier. Tallmadge was in Portage County until 1840 when Summit County was created. Guy and his wife, Abigail, were 3rd cousins.
m. 5 OCT 1781 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Abigail Allyn, b. 5 OCT 1765 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 21 FEB 1836 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
13 children: , Abigail, Abigail, Guy, James, Elizur "Eli", Frederick, Anna, Almira, Amanda, Eleanor, George, Allyn Ellsworth.
(6) Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1782 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 12 FEB 1782 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(6) Abigail Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 FEB 1784 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 1784 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
(6) Abigail Wolcott6 (Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 JUL 1785 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 3 AUG 1830 Tallmadge, Portage Co., Ohio.
m. 26 MAY 1803 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Nathan Gillett, b. 7 MAR 1781 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. Middlebury, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesNATHAN Gillett Jr. becamea freeman of Torrington CT in 1802. Moved to Western Reserve 1817.
10 children: Eliza M., Catharine Wolcott, Charlotte, Lucretia, Alexander Wolcott, Mary Ann, Amanda, Abigail "Abby", Annis, Oliver Wolcott.
(7) Eliza M. Gillett7 (Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1804 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 12 SEP 1846 .
m. 15 OCT 1820 Titus Chapman, b. 23 APR 1793 , Rutland Co., Vermont, d. 30 JUN 1866 .
Spouse NotesTITUS' family moved to Trumbull Co., Ohio, in 1806. The area became Summit Co. He served in the War of 1812. He was a farmer at Tallmadge Township, Ohio, in 1850, with wife Sophia. The Chapman family, or the descendants of Robert Chapman, one of the first settlers of Say-Brook, Conn., with genealogical notes of William Chapman, who settled in New London, Conn.; Edward Chapman, who settled at Windsor, Conn.; John Chapman, of Stonington, Conn.; and Rev. Benjamin Chapman, of Southington, Conn., by F. W. Chapman (Hartford: Case, Tiffany and Co., 1854), p. 217, 242-243
2 children: Keziah, George.
(8) Keziah Chapman8 (Eliza M. Gillett7, Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 JUL 1824 Middlebury, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 1915 Franklin, Franklin Co., Nebraska.
NotesThe Chapman family, or the descendants of Robert Chapman, one of the first settlers of Say-Brook, Conn., with genealogical notes of William Chapman, who settled in New London, Conn.; Edward Chapman, who settled at Windsor, Conn.; John Chapman, of Stonington, Conn.; and Rev. Benjamin Chapman, of Southington, Conn., by F. W. Chapman (Hartford: Case, Tiffany and Co., 1854), p. 243, 254

(8) George Chapman8 (Eliza M. Gillett7, Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 JUL 1826 ,, Ohio, d. .
NotesGEORGE was a farmer at Tallmadge Township, Ohio, in 1850.
m. Amelia , b. 1826 ,, Ohio, d. .
(7) Catharine Wolcott Gillett7 (Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 NOV 1805 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. FEB 1879 , Fulton Co., Ohio.
NotesCATHERINE moved to Summit Co. with her parents.
m. 16 JUN 1825 , Summit Co., Ohio, John Nash, b. 11 AUG 1796 Egremont, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 30 AUG 1852 Middlebury, Summit Co., Ohio.
Spouse NotesJOHN was a carpenter. He moved to Utica, New York, and then to Summit Co., Ohio. The Nash family, or records of the descendants of Thomas Nash of New Haven, Connecticut, 1640, by Sylvester Nash (Hartford: Case, Tiffany and Co., 1853), p. 246
7 children: Edgar, Alfred K., Malvina Amanda, Octavia Wolcott, Marcella Amelia, Eliza Maria, Albert G..
(8) Edgar Nash8 (Catharine Wolcott Gillett7, Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 JUN 1827 Middlebury, Summit Co., Ohio, d. AUG 1827 .
(8) Alfred K. Nash8 (Catharine Wolcott Gillett7, Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 AUG 1831 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .
(8) Malvina Amanda Nash8 (Catharine Wolcott Gillett7, Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 NOV 1833 Middlebury, Summit Co., Ohio, d. .

1 children: Milton Arthur.
(8) Milton Arthur Mason8 (Charlotte Gillett7, Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 APR 1846 Middlebury, Summit Co., Ohio, d. 15 MAY 1924 Akron, Summit Co., Ohio.
NotesARTHUR Mason was an engineer at Akron, Ohio, in 1880 with wife Jane and children Edith, Fred, and Mildred.
m. 5 JUL 1866 Erie, Erie Co., Pennsylvania, Jane Augusta Springer, b. 1845 Dorset, Bennington Co., Vermont, d. 1895 .
(7) Lucretia Gillett7 (Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 SEP 1809 ,, Connecticut, d. 1881 Connellsville, Fayette Co., Pennsylvania.
m. 26 SEP 1827 ,, Ohio, Alfred Whitter, b. 10 AUG 1800 Washington, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 1892 Connellsville, Fayette Co., Pennsylvania.
Spouse NotesALFRED was a bookkeeper at Connellsville, Pennsylvania, in 1880, with wife, Lucretia. Information about his family is from "History of Torrington, Connecticut, from its first settlement in 1737, with biographies and genealogies", by Samuel Orcutt (Albany: J. Munsell, 1878), p. 703-704; The descendants of William Witter and Hannah Churchman of Lynn, Massachusetts, by Harold John Witter (Baltimore: Gateway Press, 1991), p. 106-107
11 children: Erastus, Eliza M., Emily Amanda, Walter, Alice L., Flora E., Alfred W., Abigail D., Lucie A., George A., Mary E. L..
(8) Erastus Witter8 (Lucretia Gillett7, Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 JUL 1828 ,, Ohio, d. 7 FEB 1918 Seattle, King Co., Washington.
NotesERASTUS was a farmer at Randol, Missouri, in 1880, with Leora and Alfred Witter.
m. 29 MAY 1856 , Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, Melinda Leora Varney, b. 7 NOV 1833 Bedford, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, d. APR 1919 Seattle, King Co., Washington.

m. 16 SEP 1875 Emma Rizer, b. ABT 1850 ,, Maryland, d. .
(8) Mary E. L. Whitter8 (Lucretia Gillett7, Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 OCT 1853 , d. .
m. 2 JUN 1871 Simpson Wesley Horner, b. 1847 ,, Pennsylvania, d. 7 MAR 1913 Farmington, Oakland Co., Michigan.
Spouse NotesSIMPSON was a Methodist minister at Brownsville, Pennsylvania, 1868-70, at Connellsville, Pensylvania, 1870-1, and at Baraboo, Wisconsin, 1877-80. He was pastor of the Methodist Church at Bay City, Michigan, in 1897. His father was born in England and his mother in Pennsylvania.
(7) Alexander Wolcott Gillett7 (Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 MAY 1812 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. ABT 1814 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
(7) Mary Ann Gillett7 (Abigail Wolcott6, Guy Wolcott5, Alexander Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 FEB 1813 Torrington, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 10 OCT 1840 .
m. Edgar T. Chapman, b. 16 FEB 1807 , d. .
Spouse NotesThe Chapman family, or the descendants of Robert Chapman, one of the first settlers of Say-Brook, Conn., with genealogical notes of William Chapman, who settled in New London, Conn.; Edward Chapman, who settled at Windsor, Conn.; John Chapman, of Stonington, Conn.; and Rev.
