m. JAN 1857 John Steele, b. , d. JAN 1864 .
(8) Laura Edna Bissell8 (Theodore Bissell7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. SEP 1837 , d. .
m. 1862 Henry Cheever, b. , d. .
(8) Henry Bissell8 (Theodore Bissell7, Jerusha Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. MAY 1840 , d. .
(7) Leverett Bissell7 (Jerusha Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. SEP 1807 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 21 SEP 1872 .
m. 26 NOV 1840 Julia Watson, b. , d. .
(6) Naomi Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 OCT 1777 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 MAR 1831 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York.
m. 23 OCT 1804 , Ontario Co., New York, James Wadsworth, b. 20 APR 1768 Durham, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 7 JUN 1844 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York.
Spouse NotesJAMES was the a nephew of James Wadsworth, a Major General in the Continental Army. James graduated from Yale College in 1787. He briefly taught school at Montreal, Canada. He and his brother, William Wadsworth each obtained 2,000 acres of land in the Genesee Valley of New York. They moved there in 1790 and built a log cabin. By 1800 they owned 35,000 acres between them, most of which stayed in the family for many generations. James built a home for his new bride, Naomi, who he married in 1804. It was called "The Homestead". He was the chief founder of the town of Geneseo. He gave the proceeds from articles and lectures to establish the town's first library; advocated the idea of normal schools in 1811; accomplished the passage of a school library law in 1838, and established an institution for scientific lectures to which he gave an endowment fund of $10,000. He was the owner of vast tracts of land and in disposing of the same made the condition that 125 acres in every township be gratuitously set aside for a church, and an equal amount for a school. Over his life time, in contributed over $100,000 to education. He was a Brigadier General in the New York militia in the War of 1812.
5 children: Harriet, James Samson, William Wolcott, Cornelia, Elizabeth.
(7) Harriet Wadsworth7 (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 SEP 1805 , d. 1834 .
m. Martin Brimmer, b. , d. .
Spouse NotesMARTIN graduated from Harvard University in 1814. He was Mayor of Boston, Massachusetts.
1 children: Martin.
(8) Martin Brimmer8 (Harriet Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
NotesMARTIN graduated fron Harvard University in 1849.
(7) James Samson Wadsworth7 (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 OCT 1807 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 6 MAY 1864 Wilderness, Spotsylvania Co., Virginia.
NotesJAMES dropped out of Harvard, studied law with Daniel Webster, and was admitted to the bar in 1833. He married a "celebrated beauty" and took her to Europe for their honeymoon. Fascinated by the way the English gentry lived, he returned to Geneseo and built a palatial house called "Hartford House". He purchased 24,000 acres of government land in Ohio in 1836. He had a home in New York City, and maintained a racing stable and an impressive wine cellar. He entertained lavishly, his guests including many prominent government officials and European nobility. His house had nine servant rooms and other servants came in for the day. He divorced his first wife and remarried. In 1855, James took his family to France and England for two years. He was a leader in various agricultural movements, and was an unsuccessful candidate for Governor of New York. He was an outspoken opponent of slavery. James volunteered for the Union Army in 1861, and fought at the Battle of Bull Run and at Gettysburg. He was briefly Military Governor of Washington, D.C., and was nominated for Governor of New York in 1862. James commanded the Union troops at the Battle of The Wilderness in 1864, and died during the battle, reportedly after saying: "Steady boys. Come ahead. There isn't danger enough to harm a mouse." In 1868 he had an estate of 7,237 acres at Geneseo. The wil of James S. Wadsworth of Livingston, New York, dated 1856. recorded at Fulton Co., Ohio, states that he owned about 24,000 acres of land in Northwest Ohio, purchased fron the government in 1836. It mentions his children, Charles F. Wadsworth, Craig W. Wadsworth, James Wadsworth Jr., Cornelia, Nancy, and Elizabeth; nephew, Martin Brimmer; son-in-law, Montgomery Ritchie of Ritchey & Fitzhugh of New York City. His wife, Mary C. W. Wadsworth, is to have the home she was given in her fathers will dated 1837, and the home and library in New York City. He mentions various pieces of land formerly belonging to William A. Wadsworth, Livingston Wadsworth, and Herbert Wadsworth, infant children of William W. Wadsworth, and their mother, Emeline Wadsworth, and Charles James Murry, infant child of Elizabeth Wadsworth Murry.
m. 11 MAY 1834 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, Mary Craig Wharton, b. ABT 1811 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
6 children: Charles Frederick, Cornelia, Craig Wharton "Tic", Nancy Craig, James Wolcott, Elizabeth,
(8) Charles Frederick Wadsworth8 (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1835 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
m. Jessie Burden, b. , d. .
(8) Cornelia Wadsworth8 (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 APR 1837 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 22 SEP 1921 London,, England.
NotesCORNELIA met her second husband while touring England with her first husband. After his death she took her two sons to Paris where the eldest died a few years later. After her second marriage she lived in Ireland. She and her husband toured the American West in 1874, and she kept a diary of the experience which was published in 1918. In 1877 they purchased land in Donley Co., Texas, which became the J&A Ranch. It covered 336,000 acres, and grew to 500,000 acres in 1917. They kept 100,000 head of cattle on the ranch. Cornelia ran the ranch after her husband's death.
m. 1857 Montgomery Ritchie, b. Of Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 1864 Geneseo, Ontario Co., New York.
Spouse NotesMONTGOMERY was head of the firm, Ritchey & Fitzhugh of New York City. He helped recruit the regiment that became known as Wadsworth Guards. He was an officer in the 2nd Inf. BN., New England Guard, serving on the staff of Maj. Gen Augur. He resigned his commission in 1864 due to ill health, and died six months later.
(8) Cornelia Wadsworth8 (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 APR 1837 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 22 SEP 1921 London,, England.
NotesCORNELIA met her second husband while touring England with her first husband. After his death she took her two sons to Paris where the eldest died a few years later. After her second marriage she lived in Ireland. She and her husband toured the American West in 1874, and she kept a diary of the experience which was published in 1918. In 1877 they purchased land in Donley Co., Texas, which became the J&A Ranch. It covered 336,000 acres, and grew to 500,000 acres in 1917. They kept 100,000 head of cattle on the ranch. Cornelia ran the ranch after her husband's death.
m. 1869 John G. Adair, b. 1823 ,, Ireland, d. 1885 ,, Texas.
Spouse NotesJOHN was a wealthy Englishman, owner of Glenveagh Castle in Ireland. He came to America and opened a brokerage house in 1866. He and Charles Goodnight founded the J. A. Ranch at Armstrong Co., Texas, in 1876, and by 1882 had nearly a million acres. In 1881 he was Deputy Leiutenanant Magistrate living at North Lodge, Melton Mowbray, Leicester, England, with wife Cornelia and 15 servants. After his death his widow had a controlling interest in the J. A. Ranch
(8) Craig Wharton "Tic" Wadsworth8 (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1841 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 1 JAN 1872 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesCRAIG was mustered in as a Lieutenant in the Union Army in September 1861, and served as an aide to Gen. John F. Reynolds. After Reynold's death in 1863, he joined the staff of Gen. John Burford. He was brevetted Major, Lt. Colonel, and was made Colonel 13 March 1864. He resigned his comission 16 July 1864. In 1868 he was living at Geneseo.
m. 31 MAR 1869 Evelyn Willing Peters, b. 1845 , d. 1885 .
(8) Nancy Craig Wadsworth8 (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
m. 25 OCT 1866 M. Edward Rogers, b. , d. .
(8) James Wolcott Wadsworth8 (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 OCT 1846 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 24 DEC 1926 Washington, District of Columbia.
NotesJAMES was preparing to enter Yale College when word came of his father's death in battle. He immediately enlisted in the Army, and was appointed a Captain on the staff of Maj. Gen. G.K. Warren, commanding the 5th Army Corps of the Potomac. He was brevetted a Major for gallantry at Five Forks, 1 April 1865. After the war he managed the family estates at Geneseo, New York and built a large house called "Hartford House. He loved baseball, and financed teams on which his son, Jimmy, played. He also was a fan of harness racing. James was active in Republican politics. He was elected to the New York State Assembly, 1878-1879; State Comptroller, 1880-1881. In 1881 he was elected to fill an unexpired term in the U.S. House of Representatives, Eldridge G. Lapham, and the next year was elected for a new term from the 27th district in the 47th and 48th Congress. He served in the 52nd - 58th congress, 1891-1905 from the 13th district and served as chairman of the Committee on Agriculture. In 1898, James was given an Honorary MA degree by Yale University. He was then appointed to the State Racing Commission, and in 1915 was a member of the State Constitutional Convention. He was for many years President of the Geneseo National Bank and of the Genesee River National Bank.
m. Maria Louisa "Eloise" Travers, b. ABT 1843 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 6 MAY 1931 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York.
Spouse NotesMARIA's father had made a fortune on Wall Street. She was a first cousin of Jennie Churchill, mother of Winston Churchill.
(8) Elizabeth Wadsworth8 (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1849 , d. .
m. Arthur Post, b. , d. .
(8) Elizabeth Wadsworth8 (James Samson Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1849 , d. .
m. 28 FEB 1889 Arthur Hugh Barrymore, b. , d. 21 SEP 1844 .
Spouse NotesARTHUR was 1st and last Baron Barrymore of Fota Island, Queenstown, Ireland.
(7) William Wolcott Wadsworth7 (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1806 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
NotesWILLIAM remained a bachelor.
m. 5 JAN 1846 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Emeline Austin, b. 27 NOV 1808 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. .
3 children: William Austin, Livingston, Herbert.
(8) William Austin Wadsworth8 (William Wolcott Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1847 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
NotesWILLIAM lived alone until mid-life, in "The Homestead", which he inherited from his mother. He introduced fox hunting into the Genessee Valley in 1876. The Genessee Valley Hunt is the third oldest in the country. He served in the Rough Riders during the Spanish American War, and in the 101st Cav. Bde. in France during World War I.
m. Elizabeth Perkins, b. Of Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. .
(8) Livingston Wadsworth8 (William Wolcott Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1849 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 1855 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York.
(8) Herbert Wadsworth8 (William Wolcott Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1851 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
m. Blow, b. , d. .
(7) Cornelia Wadsworth7 (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1810 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. .
(7) Elizabeth Wadsworth7 (Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 JUL 1815 Geneseo, Livingston Co., New York, d. 8 DEC 1851 Cairo,, Egypt.
NotesELIZABETH was considered beautiful and talented, and was courted by many men. She met her future husband when he visited America in 1834. Her father refused to consent to this marriage, but after his death she visited England and married Charles there in Westminster Abbey. She died following complications caused by the birth of her son.
m. 12 DEC 1850 London,, England, Charles Augustus Murray, b. 22 NOV 1806 ,, Scotland, d. 3 JUN 1895 .
Spouse NotesCHARLES was the second son of the Earl of Dunmore. He attended Eaton and graduated from Oxford. In 1834 he visited America, where he met his future wife. He was a member of the Queen's Household, and then was attached to the British Consulate at Naples. He was appointed British Consul-General to Cairo, and then to Berne. In 1854 he became the British Minister to Persia.
1 children: Charles James.
(8) Charles James Murray8 (Elizabeth Wadsworth7, Naomi Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 NOV 1851 , d. 25 SEP 1929 .
NotesCHARLES was educated at Eton. He visited his mother's family in 1880. He purchased the Lochcarron estate, including Courthill House, in 1882. He lost part of his fortune during World War I, and then came to live primarily at Courthill House. He served as a Member of Parliament.
m. 9 AUG 1875 Anne Frenchesca Wihelmina Finch, b. , d. 16 JAN 1933 .
(6) Samuel Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 DEC 1781 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 17 FEB 1795 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(6) Elihu Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 FEB 1784 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesELIHU was a Representative to the Connecticut Legislature for East Windsor. He sold the family farm and moved to Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois in 1830. It was said that had a two room cabin, but that their furniture was shipped via New Orleans and did not arrive until the next spring. Elihu was a merchant and land owner. He purchased a large amount of land in 6 counties in Illinois between 1831 and 1849, including 952 acres at Orland Township, Cook Co., in 1835. In 1839 Elihu Woolcott of Morgan Co., Illinois, purchased 950acres of government land at Cook Co., Illinois, and 160 acres at Morgan Co., Illinois. He surveyed the route of the Sangamon and Morgan Railroad. Elihu was President of the Board of Trustees of the Jacksonville Female Academy in 1836. He ran as a candidate for Congress for the Liberty Party in 1846, against Abraham Lincoln and Cartwright. His estate was valued at $100,000. He won prizes at the 1853 Illinois State Fair for his cow and poultry. His son Elizur Wolcott was executor of his estate.
m. 27 NOV 1806 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Rachel McClure, b. 29 OCT 1783 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 APR 1822 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
7 children: Elizabeth Ann, Elihu, Hannah McClure, Samuel, Arthur, Elizur, Frances Jane.
(7) Elizabeth Ann Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 DEC 1807 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
m. 28 NOV 1832 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, Carlton H. Perry, b. 1802 Arlington, Bennington Co., Vermont, d. Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
Spouse NotesCARLTON commanded a regiment during the Civil War. In 1880 he lived at Keokuk, Iowa, where he was described as a "capitalist".
2 children: Howard Wolcott, Katharine Wolcott "Kate".
(8) Howard Wolcott Perry8 (Elizabeth Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(8) Katharine Wolcott "Kate" Perry8 (Elizabeth Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1820 ,, Illinois, d. NOV 1924 Capri, Isola Di Capri, Italy.
NotesKATHERINE resided on the Isle of Capri, Italy, with her cousin, Sarah Morrison Wolcott. When her cousin died in 1918, she returned to America. Her escort, sent from America to accompany her home was held for two days, having the same name as a noted spy operating in France. She joined the Wolcott Society in 1916.
(7) Elihu Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1808 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. .
(7) Hannah McClure Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 JUN 1811 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 31 AUG 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
m. 28 NOV 1832 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, William Kirby, b. 2 JUL 1805 Middletown, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 20 DEC 1851 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM graduated from Yale in 1827. He went to Illinois as a member of the Yale band of missionarys. In 1846 the family moved to Jacksonville. He was Superintendant of Home Missions in Illinois. His wife, Hannah, and father-in-law, Elihu Wolcott were named guardian of his children, William, Frances, Catherine, Helen, and Bessie.
7 children: Edward Payson, William Arthur, Frances Caroline, Katherine Wolcott, Helen McClure, Henry Burgess, Elizabeth Pomeroy "Bessie".
(8) Edward Payson Kirby8 (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 OCT 1833 Blackstone's Grove, Will Co., Illinois, d. 25 FEB 1917 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesEDWARD graduated from Illinois College in 1854 and taught at the West Jacksonville School, where he became Principal. He read law and was admitted to the Illinois bar in 1862, after which he opened a practace at Jacksonville. He received his LLD degree in 1880. He was a lawyer and a Morgan County Judge at Jacksonville, Illinois, and a trustee of Illinois College. He had no children in 1880. He was a member of the Illinois State Historical Society, and joined the Illinois Sons of the American Revolution in 1896 as a descendant of Gen. Erastus Wolcott.
m. 28 OCT 1862 Julia Smith Duncan, b. , d. 5 JUL 1896 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
(8) Edward Payson Kirby8 (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 OCT 1833 Blackstone's Grove, Will Co., Illinois, d. 25 FEB 1917 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesEDWARD graduated from Illinois College in 1854 and taught at the West Jacksonville School, where he became Principal. He read law and was admitted to the Illinois bar in 1862, after which he opened a practace at Jacksonville. He received his LLD degree in 1880. He was a lawyer and a Morgan County Judge at Jacksonville, Illinois, and a trustee of Illinois College. He had no children in 1880. He was a member of the Illinois State Historical Society, and joined the Illinois Sons of the American Revolution in 1896 as a descendant of Gen. Erastus Wolcott.
m. 1898 ,, Illinois, Lucinda Gallaher, b. , d. .
(8) William Arthur Kirby8 (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 AUG 1837 Mendon, Adams Co., Illinois, d. ABT 1922 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesWILLIAM was a Captain in the Civil War. He was a soap maker at Jacksonville, Illinois, in 1880, age 43, with Arabella 38, Clement 11, Harry 7, and Marian 3. He was a member of the Wolcott Society 1916-20, residing at Jacksonville, Illinois.
m. 10 SEP 1867 Arabella Clement, b. 23 MAR 1842 Port Mills,, Vermont, d. 31 DEC 1910 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
(8) Frances Caroline Kirby8 (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 JAN 1840 Mendon, Adams Co., Illinois, d. .
m. 1 AUG 1861 James McLaughlin, b. 25 OCT 1829 , d. 17 AUG 1870 .
(8) Katherine Wolcott Kirby8 (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 JUL 1842 Mendon, Adams Co., Illinois, d. 20 MAR 1880 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
m. 9 SEP 1862 Charles Emery Ross, b. , d. 1908 .
(8) Helen McClure Kirby8 (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 JAN 1845 Mendon, Adams Co., Illinois, d. 29 JUL 1923 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesHELEN was a member of the Wolcott Society in 1914 residing at Mt. Morris Park, New York., and vice-president for Eastern New York 1914-15.
m. 23 JUN 1870 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, Melatiah Everett Dwight, b. 15 OCT 1841 South Hadley, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 14 SEP 1907 Northampton, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts.
(8) Henry Burgess Kirby8 (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 MAR 1848 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 4 AUG 1849 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
(8) Elizabeth Pomeroy "Bessie" Kirby8 (Hannah McClure Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 APR 1850 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. .
NotesELIZABETH joined the Wolcott Society in 1916, residing at New York City.
(7) Samuel Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 JUL 1813 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 FEB 1886 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
Notes SAMUEL graduated from Yale College in 1833 and gave the Commencement Oration. He graduated from the Andover Theological Seminary in 1837, and was ordained in 1839. In 1837 his name is at the head of a number of Andover students who issued an anti-slavery manifesto. Samuel was a missionary to Syria from 1840 to 1843. He is said to have been one of two Americans who were the first Westerners to climb to the Jewish stronghold at Masada in 1842. Returning to America he became pastor of the Longmeadow, Massachusetts, Congregational Church in 1843. Between 1843 and 1853 he was among the principal speakers at temperance conventions. He became minister at Belchertown, Massachusetts in 1849; The High Street Congregational Church at Providence, Rhode Island in 1853; The New England Congregational Church of Chicago, Illinois, in 1859; and finally at Plymouth Congregational Church, Cleveland, Ohio, in 1862. He was at Chicago, Illinois, in 1860, with Harriet A., Samuel A., Henry R., Edward O., Harriet A., William E., Catherine E., Ann L., and Caroline G. Wolcott. Samuel was given an honorary STD degree by Marietta College, in 1863. During the Civil War, he went South with the U.S. Christian Commission. He was at Cleveland, Ohio, in 1870, with Harriett, Kate, Annie, Clara, Herbert, and Lottie. Samuel resigned his church ministry in 1874 to become Secretary of the Ohio Home Missionary Society. He was a minister at Cleveland, Ohio, in 1880. In 1880 Samuel Wolcott was on a delinquent tax list for Jacksonville, Illinois. He was the author of numerous religious tracts and hymns, the best known being, "Christ for the World we Sing", published in the 1892 hymnal of the Protestant Episcopal Church and subsequently in hymnals of many other denominations. He was the author of the 1st Wolcott Genealogy "The Wolcott Memorial" published in 1881. He is described as being tall in stature, with abundant white hair and beard. His sons in Denver built a fine home at Longmeadow, Massachusetts, for his retirement.
m. 5 SEP 1839 Westminster, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, Catharine Elizabeth Wood, b. 17 DEC 1812 Westminster, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, d. 26 OCT 1841 Beirut,, Syria.
Spouse NotesThe Vital Records of Westminster, Massachusetts read "Wood, Catherine E. and Rev. Samuel Walcott of Jacksonville, Ill. [Int. Aug 17, 1839.]
(7) Samuel Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 JUL 1813 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 FEB 1886 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
Notes SAMUEL graduated from Yale College in 1833 and gave the Commencement Oration. He graduated from the Andover Theological Seminary in 1837, and was ordained in 1839. In 1837 his name is at the head of a number of Andover students who issued an anti-slavery manifesto. Samuel was a missionary to Syria from 1840 to 1843. He is said to have been one of two Americans who were the first Westerners to climb to the Jewish stronghold at Masada in 1842. Returning to America he became pastor of the Longmeadow, Massachusetts, Congregational Church in 1843. Between 1843 and 1853 he was among the principal speakers at temperance conventions. He became minister at Belchertown, Massachusetts in 1849; The High Street Congregational Church at Providence, Rhode Island in 1853; The New England Congregational Church of Chicago, Illinois, in 1859; and finally at Plymouth Congregational Church, Cleveland, Ohio, in 1862. He was at Chicago, Illinois, in 1860, with Harriet A., Samuel A., Henry R., Edward O., Harriet A., William E., Catherine E., Ann L., and Caroline G. Wolcott. Samuel was given an honorary STD degree by Marietta College, in 1863. During the Civil War, he went South with the U.S. Christian Commission. He was at Cleveland, Ohio, in 1870, with Harriett, Kate, Annie, Clara, Herbert, and Lottie. Samuel resigned his church ministry in 1874 to become Secretary of the Ohio Home Missionary Society. He was a minister at Cleveland, Ohio, in 1880. In 1880 Samuel Wolcott was on a delinquent tax list for Jacksonville, Illinois. He was the author of numerous religious tracts and hymns, the best known being, "Christ for the World we Sing", published in the 1892 hymnal of the Protestant Episcopal Church and subsequently in hymnals of many other denominations. He was the author of the 1st Wolcott Genealogy "The Wolcott Memorial" published in 1881. He is described as being tall in stature, with abundant white hair and beard. His sons in Denver built a fine home at Longmeadow, Massachusetts, for his retirement.
m. 1 NOV 1843 Millbury, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, Harriet Amanda Pope, b. 29 JUN 1821 Oxford, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, d. 5 FEB 1901 .
11 children: Samuel Adams, Henry Roger, Edward Oliver, Harriet Agnes, William Edgar, Katharine Ellen "Kate", Mary Alice, Anna Louisa, Clara Gertrude, Herbert Walter, Charlotte Augusta "Lottie",
(8) Samuel Adams Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 SEP 1844 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 1883 Encinal, Webb Co., Texas.
NotesSAMEL attended Yale College in the class of 1866, but left in his sophmore year to enter business. In 1869 he was in the paper business at New York City. about this time he purchased a ranch in Webb Co., Texas, on the Rio Grande River, north of Lorado, where he raised livestock.
m. 25 JUL 1883 Julia Ella Neal, b. Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York, d. .
(8) Henry Roger Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 MAR 1846 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 31 MAY 1921 Honolulu, Honolulu Co., Hawaii.
NotesHENRY worked in two banks at Cleveland, Ohio. In 1864, he enlisted for 100 days service in a Cleveland Regiment that was sent to defend Washington. He then enlisted in the 143th Ohio Regiment until mustered out. He moved to Colorado in 1869, and tried mining and running a mill. In 1870 he was at Central City, Gilpin Co., Colorado. He became acting manager of the Boston & Colorado Smelting Co. at Black Hawk, becoming a stockholder and General Manager. He was also Secretary Treasurer of the Last Chance Mining and Milling Co. His brother, Edward, joined him in Colorado and the two became active in politics. He purchased land in Colorado in 1875, 1877, 1879, 1881,1888, 1890, 1893, and 1896. He was Colorado State Senator from Gilpin County from 1879 to 1882, and in 1881 was elected President of the Senate, and temporarily served as Acting Governor of Colorado. He was an unsuccessful Republican candidate for Governor in 1882 and 1896, and chairman of the state delegation to the 1888 Republican National Convention in Chicago. In 1887 he purchased a ranch at Bear Creek, Colorado. Henry was President of the Merchants National Bank of Denver, and Vice President of the First National Bank for ten years. He helped develop the Denver, Utah and Pacific Railroad and was its President. He was also a director of the Equitable Life Insurance Society. He built the observatory at Colorado College at Colorado Springs. Henry was given an honorary AM degree by Yale University in 1896, and by Colorado College in 1898. In 1905, the two brothers sailed to Europe where Edward died at Monte Carlo. Henry was living in Hawaii in 1916.
(8) Edward Oliver Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 MAR 1848 Longmeadow, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 1 MAR 1905 Monte Carlo,, Monaco.
NotesEDWARD and his brother joined a boys military company in Chicago. In 1862 the family moved to Cleveland, where he enlisted in the 150th Ohio Voluntary Regiment in 1864. During that summer he was stationed near Washington, D. C., and was with the Regiment at the battle of Ft. Stevens. He attended Yale, and in 1871 graduated from Harvard Law School, receiving a LLD degree from Yale in 1896. In 1871 he went to Colorado to join his brother, Henry. Edward practiced law at Denver in 1880. He was active in the Republican party, and was elected United States Senator from the State of Colorado in 1889, serving until 1901. He was President of the Republican National Convention at Philadelphia in 1900. In 1890 Edward bought 500 acres of land 14 miles South of Denver. There he built a large 52 room home called "Wolhurst", in 1890, at a cost of 2 million dollars. He lavishly entertained prominent Americans and European royalty there. He left it to his brother, Henry, as he had no wife or children surviving. The home, used as the Wolhurst Saddle Club, burned down in 1951. In 1881 he bought mineral rights to 4 acres of land called "Wild Cat Lode" in Lake Co.. In 1882 he and others bought mineral rights called "The American Star Lode in Boulder Co. In 1889 he bought 160 acres of coal land at Gunnison and Pitkin Co. In 1896 he and the heirs of John T. Herrick, the heirs of Sam P. Rose, Joseph Strumpf bought mineral rights to 8 acres of land in Lake Co. called "Tenderfoot". He was a great gambler at Poker and Faro, and died while visiting the casino at Monte Carlo. His biograph, "Life and Character of Edward Oliver Wolcott" by Thomas Dawson, was privately printed. A large stained glass window with his picture was placed in the Colorado Senate. Known for his eloquence and culture, he was known locally as "Edward of Navarre" because of his patronage of the Navarre, a "house of ill repute".
m. 14 JUN 1899 Buffalo, Erie Co., New York, Frances Esther Metcalfe, b. Buffalo, Erie Co., New York, d. 9 FEB 1932 New York City, New York.
Spouse NotesFRANCES was the author of a biography of herself, "Heritage of Years", published in 1932. She tells about people she had known or met, including the Grand Duke Alexis, Mark Twain, Millard Fillmore, and General Custer. As the wife of two U.S. Senators, she knew the Grants, the Clevelands, the Blaines, and other Washington D.C. notables. Grover Cleveland was the executor of her father's estate. During the last 20 years of her life, her residence in New York City was a gathering place for artists, actors, Musicians, and writers.
(8) Harriet Agnes Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 MAR 1850 Belchertown, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 1917 .
m. 2 APR 1879 , Cuyahoga Co., Ohio, Frederick Osni Vaille, b. 28 JUL 1850 Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, d. 15 MAR 1939 .
Spouse NotesFREDERICK graudated from Harvard in 1874. He and Henry Clark compiled the first Harvard Book as a souvenier for fellow Harvard graduates. He was the founder of the Denver Telephone Dispatch Company which established the first phone service between Denver, Colorado, and Black Hawk, Idaho, in 1879. This was the 17th telephone exchange in the nation. In 1880 he was superintendant of a telephone company living at Denver with wife, Harriet A. Vaille, daughter, Harriet, and sister Kate. E. Wolcott.
(8) William Edgar Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 26 APR 1852 Belchertown, Hampshire Co., Massachusetts, d. 12 MAY 1911 Lawrence, Essex Co., Massachusetts.
NotesWILLIAM graduated from Oberlin College in 1881, and was pastor of the Riverside Congregational Church at Lawrence, Massachusetts, for over 25 years. His large art collection, inherited from his brother, Senator Edward O. Wolcott, was left to the White Fund in 1911, to be placed in a museum in Lawrence when one could be built. William was an acquaintance of the poet, Robert Frost, who said, "Perhaps when that preacher looked me up after "My Butterfly" first appeared in print and talked to me about it, something Providential was happening to me. I'm sure the old gentleman didn't have the slightest idea he was having any effect on a very stubborn youngster who thought he knew what he knew. But something he said actually changed the whole course of my writing. It all became purposeful." William later recommended Frost for a teaching position. (From: Robert Frost, a Life", by Jay Parini.)
m. 26 MAR 1894 Cora Wadsworth, b. Of Methuen, Essex Co., Massachusetts, d. 25 SEP 1895 Lawrence, Essex Co., Massachusetts.
(8) Katharine Ellen "Kate" Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 AUG 1854 Providence, Providence Co., Rhode Island, d. 15 MAY 1936 Denver, Arapahoe County, After 1901 Denver Co., Colorado.
NotesKATHERINE was a bookeeper, living with her sister, Harriet, in 1880.
m. 25 NOV 1880 Denver, Arapahoe Co., Colorado, Charles Hansen Toll, b. 26 AUG 1850 Memphis, Onandago Co., New York, d. 4 DEC 1901 Denver, Arapahoe County, After 1901 Denver Co., Colorado.
Spouse NotesCHARLES graduated from Harvard College in 1872. He was the Attorney General of Colorado 1881-2.
(8) Mary Alice Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 JUL 1856 Providence, Providence Co., Rhode Island, d. 3 FEB 1858 .
(8) Anna Louisa Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 MAY 1858 Providence, Providence Co., Rhode Island, d. 17 AUG 1928 .
NotesANNA graduated from Wellesley College. She moved to Denver, Colorado in 1892 to be Principal of Wolfe Hall Episcopal School for Girls. In 1898 she founded the Wolcott School for Girls in Denver. She was a Regent of University of Colorado from 1910 to 1916, and a delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1923 and a member of the Republican National Committee in 1924. She was vice president of the Wolcott Society for Colorado in 1913.


"As Miss Anna Louise Wolcott she has been, for many years, one of the prominent educators of the state. Founded, and has sinee conducted, the Miss Wolcott School for Girls in Denver. A Regent of the State University since 1910; she is also one of the Board of Managers of the American School of Archacology. at Santa Fe. New Mexico. In January. 1913, she married Mr. Joel F. Vaile
m. JAN 1913 Joel Frederick Vaille, b. 1848 , d. 3 AUG 1916 King, San Bernardino Co., California.
Spouse NotesJOEL was an attorney for the Rio Grande Railroad.
(8) Clara Gertrude Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 DEC 1859 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. DEC 1939 .
NotesCLARA graduated from Smith College in 1883.
(8) Herbert Walter Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 NOV 1861 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 28 NOV 1941 Los Angeles, Los Angeles Co., California.
NotesHERBERT graduated from Yale College in 1884. He became involved in the management of electric railroads in the Leavenworth, Ohio, area, where he was the first general manager of the Kansas City Leavenworth Electric Railroad Company. He was at Leavenworth in 1900. The power house of the railroad was located at Conner, Kansas, half way to Kansas City. Conner was renamed Wolcott in Herbert's honor in 1902. Herbert was a Republican and an Ohio state senator. In 1917 he was a large landowner in Texas. He gave the principal address at the 1920 Wolcott Society runion, and was President of the Society of Descendants of Henry Wolcott, 1922-1923.
m. 5 OCT 1891 Nettie M. Gabriel, b. , d. 24 JUN 1953 Buffalo, Erie Co., New York.
Spouse NotesNETTIE graduated from Oberlin College.
(8) Charlotte Augusta "Lottie" Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 OCT 1863 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 16 APR 1912 Fort Leavenworth, Leavenworth Co., Kansas.
NotesCHARLOTTE graduated from Smith College in 1886.
m. 5 JAN 1904 Charles Francis Bates, b. 25 DEC 1862 Monroe, Monroe Co., Michigan, d. 1943 .
Spouse NotesCHARLES received a law degree from Columbia University in 1892. He served in the Spanish American War, and was commanding officer of Camp McArthur at Waco, Texas, during World War I. Retiring after 24 years of military service, he practiced law at Bronxville, New York. He wrote several books, including "Custer's Indian Battles" in 1936. His papers are now in the Yale University Collection of Western Americana.
(8) Charlotte Augusta "Lottie" Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 OCT 1863 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 16 APR 1912 Fort Leavenworth, Leavenworth Co., Kansas.
NotesCHARLOTTE graduated from Smith College in 1886.
m. 21 OCT 1889 , Cook Co., Illinois, John H. Purdy, b. , d. .
(8) Charlotte Augusta "Lottie" Wolcott8 (Samuel Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 OCT 1863 Chicago, Cook Co., Illinois, d. 16 APR 1912 Fort Leavenworth, Leavenworth Co., Kansas.
NotesCHARLOTTE graduated from Smith College in 1886.
m. 26 MAR 1885 , Cook Co., Illinois, Robert C. Wright, b. , d. .
(7) Arthur Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 FEB 1815 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 28 NOV 1873 Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
NotesARTHUR was a merchant at Keokuk, Iowa, in 1850. He was at Keokuk in 1860 with Clara B. and Sarah M. Wolcott. His burial record says he was born 10 April 1815.
m. 12 JUL 1849 Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa, Sarah Ann Morrison, b. 10 DEC 1828 ,, Pennsylvania, d. 27 JAN 1851 .
1 children: Sarah Morrison.
(8) Sarah Morrison Wolcott8 (Arthur Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1850 , d. 7 FEB 1917 Capri, Isola Di Capri, Italy.
NotesSARAH was adopted by her aunt and took the name, Sarah Morrison Perry. At the time of her death, her niece, Kathryn Wolcott Perry, was living with her. She joined the Wolcott Society in 1915, residing at Capri, Italy.
(7) Arthur Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 FEB 1815 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 28 NOV 1873 Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
NotesARTHUR was a merchant at Keokuk, Iowa, in 1850. He was at Keokuk in 1860 with Clara B. and Sarah M. Wolcott. His burial record says he was born 10 April 1815.
m. 1854 Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa, Clara Belknap, b. ABT 1820 Newburgh, Orange Co., New York, d. 24 JAN 1906 Keokuk, Lee Co., Iowa.
Spouse NotesCLARA came to Iowa from Ohio in the early 1850s, and was a long time member of the Presbyterian Church at Keokuk
3 children: Anne, Arthur Ellsworth, Bertha Belknap.
(8) Anne Wolcott8 (Arthur Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(8) Arthur Ellsworth Wolcott8 (Arthur Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1861 ,, Iowa, d. 13 OCT 1862 .
NotesARTHUR died age 13 months, 13 days.
(8) Bertha Belknap Wolcott8 (Arthur Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 APR 1865 , d. .
(7) Elizur Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 AUG 1817 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 10 MAR 1901 Berkeley, Alameda Co., California.
NotesELIZUR graduated from Yale in 1839, was a early member of the "Skull and Bones" Society. He was educated as a physician, but engaged in Railroading and milling. He was roadmaster for the Wabash Railroad, and was a member of the Jacksonville, Illinois, City Council and Board of Education. In 1860 Eleizer Wolcot was a "gentleman" at Jacksonville, Illinois, age 42, with Martha 35, Eddie 9, and Elihu 5 mo. In 1870, he and wife and daughters Edith and May were living at Jacksonville, where he is described as a retired miller. He planned and carried out a city system of water-works for Jacksonville, and planned the Diamond Grove Cemetery.
m. 15 JUL 1846 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, Martha Lyman Dwight, b. 25 APR 1824 ,, Massachusetts, d. 9 JAN 1900 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
Spouse NotesMARTHA's name is Marela D. Wolcott on her death record.
4 children: Leofwyn, Edith Dwight, Elihu, Mary Matoon.
(8) Leofwyn Wolcott8 (Elizur Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 NOV 1847 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 7 AUG 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
(8) Edith Dwight Wolcott8 (Elizur Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 18 DEC 1850 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 16 NOV 1915 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
m. 22 DEC 1897 , Morgan Co., Illinois, John Herbert Davis, b. Of Lynchburg,, Virginia, d. .
(8) Elihu Wolcott8 (Elizur Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 DEC 1859 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 29 AUG 1860 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
(8) Mary Matoon Wolcott8 (Elizur Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 MAY 1863 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. .
m. 22 DEC 1886 , Morgan Co., Illinois, Edward Bull Clapp, b. 14 APR 1856 , d. .
(7) Frances Jane Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 MAR 1819 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 11 OCT 1871 Hot Springs, Garland Co., Arkansas.
Notes"My Beloved Wife, Frances Wolcott Lewis, a native of East Windsor, Conn., died at Hot Springs, Ark., October 11th (1831?, 1871?)
m. 2 JUN 1849 Mobile, Mobile Co., Alabama, Barbour Lewis, b. ABT 1814 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. .
Spouse NotesBARBOUR served as a Major during the Civil War. He was a lawyer, a Member of Congress for Tennessee, and a Judge.
(6) Elihu Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 FEB 1784 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesELIHU was a Representative to the Connecticut Legislature for East Windsor. He sold the family farm and moved to Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois in 1830. It was said that had a two room cabin, but that their furniture was shipped via New Orleans and did not arrive until the next spring. Elihu was a merchant and land owner. He purchased a large amount of land in 6 counties in Illinois between 1831 and 1849, including 952 acres at Orland Township, Cook Co., in 1835. In 1839 Elihu Woolcott of Morgan Co., Illinois, purchased 950acres of government land at Cook Co., Illinois, and 160 acres at Morgan Co., Illinois. He surveyed the route of the Sangamon and Morgan Railroad. Elihu was President of the Board of Trustees of the Jacksonville Female Academy in 1836. He ran as a candidate for Congress for the Liberty Party in 1846, against Abraham Lincoln and Cartwright. His estate was valued at $100,000. He won prizes at the 1853 Illinois State Fair for his cow and poultry. His son Elizur Wolcott was executor of his estate.
m. 13 MAY 1823 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Juliana Wolcott, b. 9 APR 1791 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 30 NOV 1832 .
3 children: Helen Maria, Julia Ann, Ellen Louise "Ella".
(7) Helen Maria Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 JUN 1824 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 13 MAY 1831 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(7) Julia Ann Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 JUN 1826 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 14 JUL 1910 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesJULIA was a student at the Jacksonville Female Academy, graduating in 1845.
m. 19 NOV 1846 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, William Chauncy Carter, b. 2 APR 1820 New Canaan, Fairfield Co., Connecticut, d. 9 DEC 1896 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
Spouse NotesWILLIAM came to Illinois in 1833. The family settled on a farm four miles south of Jacksonville in Morgan Co. He graduated from Illinois College in 1845 and taught school for a few years. He then purchased a farm next to his father's farm. His barn was a way station on the "Underground Railroad". In 1873 he moved into Jacksonbville, where he served eight years on the city council and Director of the school.
9 children: Samuel Wolcott, William Chauncey, Edwin, William Wallace, Ella Marian, Walter Lee, Truman Post, Herbert, Helen Hooker.
(8) Samuel Wolcott Carter8 (Julia Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 APR 1849 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. .
NotesSAMUEL was a farmer at Joy Prarie.
m. 14 MAR 1876 Hannah Joy, b. , d. .
(8) William Chauncey Carter8 (Julia Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1851 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. INFANT .
(8) Edwin Carter8 (Julia Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1852 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. INFANT .
(8) William Wallace Carter8 (Julia Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 FEB 1854 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. .
NotesWILLIAM took over his father's farm in Morgan Co., Illinois.
m. 6 MAY 1885 Kittie Sibert, b. , d. .
(8) Ella Marian Carter8 (Julia Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 NOV 1855 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 14 AUG 1883 .
(8) Walter Lee Carter8 (Julia Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 31 MAR 1861 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. .
m. 8 JAN 1884 Clara Rucy, b. , d. .
(8) Truman Post Carter8 (Julia Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 AUG 1863 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. .
NotesTRUMAN was a professor at Jacksonville, Illinois.
m. 31 JUL 1894 Elizabeth Demotte, b. , d. .
(8) Herbert Carter8 (Julia Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 OCT 1870 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 24 MAY 1899 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesHERBERT graduated from Illinois College in 1892, and from Hahnemann Medical College in Philadelphia in 1895. He had a druggist business in Jacksonville for a few yearsm and then returned to Philadelphia to study diseases of the nose and throat.
(8) Helen Hooker Carter8 (Julia Ann Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 OCT 1870 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 11 JUN 1871 .
(7) Ellen Louise "Ella" Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 JUN 1828 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 15 APR 1912 Elmira, Chemung Co., New York.
NotesELLEN had a dermatalogical illness and spent much time undergoing various cures. After the death of her father she had financial problems. She worked for the Sanitary Comission as a nurse during the Civil War, where she was a correspondent of Dorthea Dix. After the war she was a librarian at Elmira, New York. In 1880 she was living alone at Elmira. Her letters and papers are in the Thomas J. Dodd Research Center, at the University of Connecticut Library. Ellen L. Wolcott of Elmira, New York, is reported deceased in the 1912 Society report, and is described as "a loyal member of the society from its beginning."
m. McVaugh, b. , d. .
1 children: Archie.
(8) Archie McVaugh8 (Ellen Louise "Ella" Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. 28 JUN 1912 Cleveland, Cuyahoga Co., Ohio.
NotesARCHIE was killed.
(6) Elihu Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 FEB 1784 South Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 DEC 1858 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
NotesELIHU was a Representative to the Connecticut Legislature for East Windsor. He sold the family farm and moved to Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois in 1830. It was said that had a two room cabin, but that their furniture was shipped via New Orleans and did not arrive until the next spring. Elihu was a merchant and land owner. He purchased a large amount of land in 6 counties in Illinois between 1831 and 1849, including 952 acres at Orland Township, Cook Co., in 1835. In 1839 Elihu Woolcott of Morgan Co., Illinois, purchased 950acres of government land at Cook Co., Illinois, and 160 acres at Morgan Co., Illinois. He surveyed the route of the Sangamon and Morgan Railroad. Elihu was President of the Board of Trustees of the Jacksonville Female Academy in 1836. He ran as a candidate for Congress for the Liberty Party in 1846, against Abraham Lincoln and Cartwright. His estate was valued at $100,000. He won prizes at the 1853 Illinois State Fair for his cow and poultry. His son Elizur Wolcott was executor of his estate.
m. 17 SEP 1835 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Sarah Choate Crocker, b. 17 AUG 1797 , d. 4 AUG 1844 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
2 children: Sarah Elizabeth, Richmond,
(7) Sarah Elizabeth Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 MAY 1837 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 6 SEP 1838 Jacksonville, Morgan Co., Illinois.
(7) Richmond Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 JAN 1840 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 14 MAY 1908 Springfield, Sangamon Co., Illinois.
NotesRICHMOND gratuated from Illinois College in 1859. He was living at Morgan Co., Illinois, in 1860, with the Kirby family, and listed on the census as a physician. He enlisted as a Private in Co. B, 10th Illinois Infantry in 1861. In April 1861 he was a hospital steward at Jacksonville. He was later comissioned a Lieutenant, and then promoted to Captain. He was discharged in September, 1864. He was admitted to the bar in June 1865, and was a lawyer at Springfield, Illinois, where he was living with Jennie, Cordelia, and Lucy in 1880. He was one of the organizers and the first Secretary of the Illinois Sons of the American Revolution in 1889. Richmond wrote short stories, several of which were published in books and magazines in the 1860s. In 1870 Richmond Wolcott of Sagamon Co., Illinois, purchased 160 acres of government land at Otter Tail Co., Minnesota, and 12 acres at Grant Co., Minnesota.
m. 11 JUL 1865 , Sangamon Co., Illinois, Jane Van Vechten "Jennie" Satler, b. 17 OCT 1841 Waverly,, Illinois, d. 9 FEB 1920 St. Louis, St. Louis Co., Missouri.
3 children: Cordelia Leland, Lucy Salter, Ella Richmond.
(8) Cordelia Leland Wolcott8 (Richmond Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 MAY 1866 Springfield, Sangamon Co., Illinois, d. .
NotesCORDELIA was DAR member #63448 of Bloomington.
m. 4 OCT 1897 , Sangamon Co., Illinois, Parkinson Unwin, b. , d. .
(8) Lucy Salter Wolcott8 (Richmond Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 NOV 1867 Springfield, Sangamon Co., Illinois, d. .
m. 21 MAY 1889 , Sangamon Co., Illinois, Charles Ryan, b. , d. 31 MAR 1905 .
(8) Lucy Salter Wolcott8 (Richmond Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 NOV 1867 Springfield, Sangamon Co., Illinois, d. .
m. 12 APR 1909 Edwin W. Bear, b. , d. .
(8) Ella Richmond Wolcott8 (Richmond Wolcott7, Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 JUL 1873 ,, Illinois, d. 3 FEB 1875 .
m. 14 FEB 1888 , Mc Henry Co., Illinois, E. Stevens, b. , d. .
(7) Richmond Wolcott7 (Elihu Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 JAN 1840 , Morgan Co., Illinois, d. 14 MAY 1908 Springfield, Sangamon Co., Illinois.
NotesRICHMOND gratuated from Illinois College in 1859. He was living at Morgan Co., Illinois, in 1860, with the Kirby family, and listed on the census as a physician. He enlisted as a Private in Co. B, 10th Illinois Infantry in 1861. In April 1861 he was a hospital steward at Jacksonville. He was later comissioned a Lieutenant, and then promoted to Captain. He was discharged in September, 1864. He was admitted to the bar in June 1865, and was a lawyer at Springfield, Illinois, where he was living with Jennie, Cordelia, and Lucy in 1880. He was one of the organizers and the first Secretary of the Illinois Sons of the American Revolution in 1889. Richmond wrote short stories, several of which were published in books and magazines in the 1860s. In 1870 Richmond Wolcott of Sagamon Co., Illinois, purchased 160 acres of government land at Otter Tail Co., Minnesota, and 12 acres at Grant Co., Minnesota.
m. Ida Anneliza , b. , d. 1 OCT 1861 .
Spouse NotesIDA's relationship to Richmond is unknown, but she is buried in the same cemetery with his daughter.
(6) Sophia Wolcott6 (Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 MAR 1786 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 8 JUN 1870 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 19 OCT 1807 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Martin Ellsworth, b. 17 APR 1783 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 2 NOV 1857 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesMARTIN graduated from Yale College in 1801. He inherited his father's home and lands at Windsor.
11 children: , Oliver, Samuel Wolcott, Abigail Wolcott, Frederick, , Delia Williams, , Ellen Sophia, , Henry Martin.
(7) Ellsworth7 (Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1808 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. ABT 1808 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(7) Oliver Ellsworth7 (Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 APR 1810 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 22 AUG 1841 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesOLIVER graduated from Yale College in 1830. He was killed being kicked by a horse.
(7) Samuel Wolcott Ellsworth7 (Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 JAN 1812 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 3 FEB 1882 Lafayette, Tippecanoe Co., Indiana.
m. 27 NOV 1834 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Eleanor Drake, b. 25 DEC 1813 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 6 MAR 1902 Lafayette, Tippecanoe Co., Indiana.
4 children: Sophia Wolcott, Samuel Wolcott, Emma, Emma.
(8) Sophia Wolcott Ellsworth8 (Samuel Wolcott Ellsworth7, Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 SEP 1835 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 26 SEP 1893 .

m. 24 MAR 1880 James W. Eldridge, b. , d. .
(7) Abigail Wolcott Ellsworth7 (Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 JAN 1814 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 6 APR 1874 Springfield, Hampshire, after 1812 Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
m. 25 DEC 1838 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, David Aiken Hall, b. 16 OCT 1795 Grafton, Windham Co., Vermont, d. 24 DEC 1870 Washington, District of Columbia.
6 children: Ellen Ellsworth, Alice Lindsley, William Frederick, Martin Ellsworth, Frances Elizabeth, Martha Barker.
(8) Ellen Ellsworth Hall8 (Abigail Wolcott Ellsworth7, Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 30 JUN 1840 Washington, District of Columbia, d. 20 APR 1900 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 20 NOV 1861 Theodore Alden Curtis, b. 23 JAN 1831 Sharon, Norfolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 27 OCT 1914 Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts.
(8) Alice Lindsley Hall8 (Abigail Wolcott Ellsworth7, Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 AUG 1842 Washington, District of Columbia, d. .
NotesALICE was a member of the DAR #1547.
m. 9 MAY 1877 Cornelius C. Wyckoff, b. , d. .
(8) William Frederick Hall8 (Abigail Wolcott Ellsworth7, Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 AUG 1844 Washington, District of Columbia, d. 1898 ,, Massachusetts.
m. 15 DEC 1869 Eliza Burke, b. Springfield, Windsor Co., Vermont, d. .
(8) Martin Ellsworth Hall8 (Abigail Wolcott Ellsworth7, Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 SEP 1847 Washington, District of Columbia, d. 21 FEB 1904 Norfolk, Norfolk Co., Virginia.
NotesMARTIN graduated from the U. S. Naval Academy in 1869.
m. 2 OCT 1878 Mary C. Cushing, b. 1 JAN 1855 Lowell, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. 8 OCT 1928 .
(8) Frances Elizabeth Hall8 (Abigail Wolcott Ellsworth7, Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 AUG 1851 , d. .
(8) Martha Barker Hall8 (Abigail Wolcott Ellsworth7, Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 DEC 1855 Washington, District of Columbia, d. 1 SEP 1903 New York City, New York.
NotesMARTHA changed her given name to Martha Wolcott.
m. 23 MAY 1883 Springfield, Hampden Co., Massachusetts, James Ripley Wellman "Ripley" Hitchcock, b. 3 JUL 1857 Fitchburg, Worcester Co., Massachusetts, d. 4 MAY 1918 New York City, New York.
Spouse NotesJAMES graduated from Harvard in 1877. He was a journalist and literary advisor; special correspondent for the New York Tribune 1882-3, art critic for the Tribune 1882-90, literary advisor Appleton & Co. 1890-1902, etc.. He was editor and author of many books on art, history, and biography.
(7) Frederick Ellsworth7 (Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 APR 1816 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 24 SEP 1878 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 27 APR 1846 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Elizabeth Halsey, b. ABT 1820 ,, Connecticut, d. Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(7) Ellsworth7 (Sophia Wolcott6, Jerusha Wolcott5, Erastus Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. ABT 1818 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. ABT 1818 East Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut.

Spouse NotesHENRY was Connecticut state Treasurer.
5 children: Henry Ellsworth, George Edwin, William Wolcott, Frederick, Mary Ellen.

Spouse NotesFREDERICK graduated from Yale College in 1877.

NotesELLEN was born Sophia and her given name was changed to Ellen in childhood.
