(8) Bessie May Kelley8 (Margaret Sara Henderson7, Helen Myers6, Sally Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 JUN 1873 Lyons, Ionia Co., Michigan, d. 29 APR 1967 Lyons, Ionia Co., Michigan.
m. 4 JAN 1896 Lyons, Ionia Co., Michigan, Edward Harrison Allen, b. 28 MAR 1864 New Albany, Bradford Co., Pennsylvania, d. 11 FEB 1949 Lyons, Ionia Co., Michigan.
(7) Daniel C. Henderson7 (Helen Myers6, Sally Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
m. Rose Woodruff, b. , d. .
(7) James E. Henderson7 (Helen Myers6, Sally Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
m. Kate Alpine, b. , d. .
(7) John D. Henderson7 (Helen Myers6, Sally Griswold5, Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 OCT 1851 , d. .
m. Cora Coon, b. , d. .
(5) Sally Griswold5 (Ursula Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. Lyme, New London Co., Connecticut, d. .
m. Chandler, b. , d. .
(4) Oliver Wolcott4 (Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 NOV 1726 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 1 DEC 1797 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesOLIVER WOLCOTT, born 20 Nov. 1726 Windsor, Connecticut; died 1 Dec. 1797 Litchfield, Connecticut, buried East Cemetery, Litchfield. Oliver graduated first in his class from Yale in 1747. In the same year he was commissioned a Captain by Gov. Clinton of New York and raised a company of men which he lead in defense of the northern frontiers against the French and the Indians. After the peace of Aix-la-Chapelle his unit was disbanded and he returned to Connecticut and studied medicine under his brother, Alexander. Oliver moved from Goshen, Connecticut, to Litchfield about 1750. In that year his father was elected Governor of Connecticut. From 1751 to 1771 he was Sheriff of Litchfield County. In 1753 he built a large house at Litchfield, on land given him by his father. This home is the oldest house at Litchfield, and was lately occupied by his descendant, Mrs. Alice Wolcott Sherman. Washington and Lafayette visited the home, and Washington stayed here on his visit to Litchfield in 1780. He married Laura Collins 21 January 1755, by whom he had five children, one dying in infancy. One son, Oliver Wolcott. Jr., was a Governor of Connecticut. Oliver was elected a Representative to the Connecticut General Assembly in 1764 and served until 1770. He was an Assistant to the Governor from 1771 to 1786. He was also a Judge of Probate from 1772 to 1795, and chief Judge of the Court of Common Pleas from 1774 to 1786. He rose through the ranks of the Connecticut militia, from Captain to Major-General. In 1775, he was appointed one of the Commissioners of Indian Affairs, charged with inducing the Indians to remain neutral during the struggle with Great Britain. He was appointed as a representative of Connecticut to the Continental Congress in 1776, taking his seat there in January, 1776. Becoming ill in June, during the discussion of the Declaration of Independence, he returned to Connecticut. He led fourteen units of the Connecticut militia to the defense of New York. On 9 July, 1776, a group of patriots tore down the lead statue of George III on Bowling Green in New York City. Oliver had it taken by cart to his home at Litchfield. His family and neighbors melted the lead in the Wolcott's apple orchard, molding 42,000 bullets for Washington's army. He returned to Philadelphia where he signed his name to the Declaration of Independence on 4 September 1776. Oliver spent the summer of 1777 recruiting troops from Connecticut, and with the rank of Major General, he commanded the Connecticut militia at the Battle of Saratoga, where British General Burgoyne was defeated. He rejoined the Continental Congress at York, Pennsylvania, and went with it when it moved to Baltimore in the winter of 1777-8. He signed the Articles of Confederation as representative for Connecticut on 15 Nov, 1777. In 1779 he commanded a division of militia defending the Connecticut coast. In 1780, he was one of the three commissioners appointed to arrange for supplies for the French troops at Newport, Rhode Island. He served with the militia until 1780, and, except for 1799, he represented Connecticut in the Continental Congress until 1784. In 1784 and 1785 he was one of the Commissioners for Indian Affairs charged with establishing terms of peace with the Iroquois. He helped negotiate the "Purchase of 1784", which legally cleared all Indians from the land northwest of the Allegheny River. Oliver, and his sons, Oliver and Frederick, were given land grants at Elmore, New Hampshire, for his service in the wars. He was also given land near Wolcott, New Hampshire, named for him because of his support for making New Hampshire a state. He was a member of the Susquehanna Company, a group of Connecticut investors who sold land in the Wyoming Valley to settlers. This land was claimed by both Connecticut and Pennsylvania. At a meeting of the Susquehanna Company in 1785, he is said to have presented a draft of a constitution for a new state in that area, to be called "Westmoreland". He was involved in negotiations for resolving the "Wyoming Controversy". The resuts of this negotiation was that the Wyoming Valley belonged to Pennsylvania. He was also involved in negotiating a land dispute between Vermont and New York. Oliver was a slave owner. In 1786 he freed a slave named Caesar, giving him the surname, Jamus. In 1790, his family at Litchfield consisted of 3 males over 16, 1 female, and 6 slaves. From 1786 to 1796 Oliver was Lieutenant Governor of Connecticut. He was an ardent Federalist. He was granted an honorary LLD degree by Yale University. In 1796 he was a Presidential Elector and voted for John Adams. Upon the death of Governor Huntington, he became Governor of Connecticut, holding office until he died the following year. The town of Farmingbury, Connecticut, changed it's name to Wolcott when Oliver cast the tie-breaking vote in 1796, to allow it to seperate from the town of Waterbury, of which it had been a part. Oliver was described as tall, erect, and dignified, with a dark complexion. Two portraits of him, painted by Ralph Earle, have survived. One was presented to the State Senate of Connecticut by his grandson, Dr. John Stoughton Wolcott. It is now in the Connecticut State Library. The other is owned by the Connecticut Historical Society. Oliver's letters and papers are deposited with the Connecticut Historical Society. His statue was one of those placed on the Connecticut State House, added in 1916 by a vote of various Connecticut patriotic societies.
m. 21 JAN 1755 Laura Collins, b. 1 JAN 1732 Guilford, New Haven Co., Connecticut, d. 19 APR 1794 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesLAURA's portrait, painted by Ralph Earl, is in the Virginia Art Museum in Richmond, Virginia.
5 children: Oliver, Oliver, Laura, Mariann, Frederick,
(5) Oliver Wolcott5 (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 31 AUG 1757 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 13 SEP 1757 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
(5) Oliver Wolcott5 (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 11 JAN 1760 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 1 JUN 1833 New York City, New York.
NotesOLIVER attended Nathaniel Beckwith's grammar school, and in 1773 enrolled at Yale College. He served with the Litchfield militia in 1777 when they fought to keep the British from capturing the colonist's supplies at Danbury. He graduated from Yale in 1778, at the age of 18, and served as an military aide to his father in 1779. He studied law at Litchfield, and was admitted to the bar in 1781. He was a member of the Susquehanna Land Company in 1786. Oliver began practicing law in Hartford, and became a clerk in the state Treasury office, and was a member of the pay-table committee from 1782 to 1788, Connecticut State Comptroller of Public Accounts 1788-9, Auditor 1789-91, Comptroller of the U.S. Treasury 1791-5, and U.S. Secretary of the Treasury 1795-1800, succeeding Alexander Hamilton in the Cabinets of Presidents Washington and Adams. He resigned due to slander from his Republican opponents, being accused of starting a fire in the Treasury office to conceal peculations. Oliver was appointed by President Adams as a Judge of the Circuit Court in 1801, and served until 1802. He then established a mercantile business in New York City, where he was President of the Merchants' Bank of the City of New York from 1803 to 1804. He was living in Ward 2, New York City, in 1810, with a family of 1 male born before 1765 (Oliver), 1 male born 1765-85 (servant ?), 2 males born 1800-10 (Oliver, John), 2 females born 1775-85 (servants ?), and 2 females born 1785-95 (Laura, Elizabeth). These may have included his Negro servants, Julia b. 1780, Peggy Zillah born 1786, Chloe born 1788, and Chloe born 1791. He was one of the founders, and President of the Bank of North America from 1812 to 1814. Oliver and his brother, Frederick, established a large woolen mill on the Naugatuck River in Torrington Township in 1813, and the village of Orleans there was changed to Wolcottville in their honor. This became the city of Torrington in 1881. In 1815 Oliver was an unsuccessful candidate for Governor of Connecticut on the Democratic ticket. He was elected Governor of Connecticut in 1817, and was President of the Connecticut Constitutional Convention in 1818. He served as Governor until 1827. He was an ardent Federalist, an intimated friend and advisor of Washington, Adams and Hamilton, and for some time was the last surviving member of Washington's Cabinet. Oliver was associated with Julius Demming and Benjamin Tallmadge in the Litchfield China Trading Company. One of their ships, "The Trident", sailed between America and China for 14 years. Oliver was Grand Master of the Masonic Lodge of Connecticut from 1818 to 1820. He was awarded honorary LLD degrees from Yale, Princeton, and Brown Universities. Oliver purchased a large home at Litchfield near his father's house where his brother, Frederick, lived. He planted 13 sycamore trees along South St. at Litchfield, commemorating the 13 colonies. All but one of these were killed by disease, so Oliver and his brother planted elm trees to replace them. After retiring from public service, Oliver lived with his son, John, in New York City. His will left "to my beloved and only surviving son, Doctor John Stoughton Wolcott, who resides with me and is the protector of my declining years," all his books and papers and household effects and his home and property at Litchfield; $100 to his son-in-law William Gracie; and the remainder to be divided between his children, John and Laura. He requested that John provide for the support and education of his grandson, Oliver WolcottIV. In 1844 his sole surviving heirs were Mrs. Laura Gibbs of New York City, and a grandson, Oliver Wolcott of Litchfield, Connecticut.

"28 Jan. 1796, Philadelphia: letter from Wm. V. Murray to George McHenry on his nomination as Secretary of War: ... as to the Salary, it will maintain you in that easy style of elegant but quiet accomodation which I think you love at all events it does Wolcott & Pickering. The first lives in Fourth South, at the corner of Spruce, in a
neat house of two rooms, one small, on a floor and must I think live within his means. He is a very worthy man & quite equal to his duty; his wife one of the mildest & most amiable women in town an excellent manager, kind but economical.

Oliver's portrait was presented to the Connecticut State Senate by his son, Dr. John Stoughton Wolcott. A facimile of it was put on the 2 cent Revenue Stamp in 1945. His letters and papers were deposited with the Conneticut Historical Society.

A painting of Oliver dated 1806 said to have been painted in 1806 for the Hon. Josiah Quincy and bequeathed by him to Oliver Wolcott Gibbs (1822-1908); or alternatively, it was given by the subject to his daughter, Mrs. George Gibbs III (Laura Wolcott), who gave it to her son, Oliver Wolcott Gibbs. Oliver Wolcott Gibbs' niece, Laura Henriette d'Oremieulx, later Mrs. J. West Roosevelt, New York, great-granddaughter of the subject; her gift in 1933 to her son, Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, New York (died July 15, 1953); owned by 1966, Oliver Wolcott Roosevelt, Jr., Birmingham, Alabama (on permanent loan to Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham, in 1997, still owned by O.W. Roosevelt, Jr.. A copy of this portrait is owned by George Gibbs, New York. See also the copy by G.L. Nelson owned by New-York Historical Society, New York. This copy by Nelson is owned by First National City Bank of New York (Citibank). A copy is at the United States Treasury Department.
m. 1 JUN 1785 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, Elizabeth Stoughton, b. 27 OCT 1767 Windsor, Hartford Co., Connecticut, d. 25 SEP 1805 New York City, New York.
7 children: John Stoughton, Oliver, Laura, Elizabeth Stoughton, Oliver Stoughton, John Stoughton, Henry.
(6) John Stoughton Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 28 AUG 1787 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 4 FEB 1789 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
(6) Oliver Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 MAY 1790 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 17 JUL 1791 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
(6) Laura Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 10 APR 1794 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 10 DEC 1870 New York City, New York.
NotesLAURA was strong and fortright, according to her grandson. She was an ardent abolitionist, and helped hide runaway slaves in New York City. Later in life she became an amateur artist.
m. 27 DEC 1810 New York City, New York, George Gibbs, b. 7 JAN 1776 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island, d. 6 AUG 1833 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
Spouse NotesGEORGE was a gentleman farmer on Long Island. He had a large house called "Sunswick", near Astoria, New York, overlooking the East River. He was an amateur scientist and mineralologist. The mineral, Gibbsite, was named for him. He was named vice-president of the New York Lyceum of Natural History in 1822. His huge collection of rocks and minerals, formed by the purchase of European collections and his own purchases, was the largest in the United States. The collection was purchased by Yale University in 1825. His large collection of books, purchased when he was in Europe, is now in the Yale University library. The Smithsonian Institution's Museum of American History has a five piece silver tea set with the Gibbs coat-of-arms, showing three battle-axes, made by Chaudron of Philadelphia, probably before 1819. This was owned by George and Laura, and may have been a wedding present. His father-in-law, Oliver Wolcott, lived with him at the time of Oliver's death.
7 children: George, Mary, Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza", Oliver Wolcott "Wolcott", Alfred, Laura Wolcott, Francis Sarason.
(7) George Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 JUL 1815 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 19 APR 1873 New Haven, Oswego Co., New York.
NotesGEORGE attended the Round Hill School of Northampton, and graduated from Harvard College in 1838. In his early 20s he travelled extensively in Europe, making scetches of towns in Germany and Switzerland. This sketch book was in the possession of his descendant, Robert Nowell Williams Jr.. He was a lawyer, antiquarian, and Librarian of the New York Historical Society. In 1846 he published "Memoirs of the Administration of Washington and John Adams, Edited from the Papers of Oliver Wolcott, Secretary of the Treasury". George marched overland from St. Louis to Oregon in 1854. He was appointed Collector of the Port of Astoria, Oregon, in 1854, and served on the Boundary Commission. He was appointed to the boundary survey team in 1857. In 1860 he returned East and was employed by the Smithsonian Institution editing documents about Indian culture. He was the author of several works on Indian languages published by the Smithsonian. He moved to New Haven, Connecticut in 1871. He gave the chest owned by Henry Wolcott, the immigrant, to the Connecticut Historical Society. He married his first cousin.
m. 11 APR 1871 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island, Mary Kane Gibbs, b. 19 JAN 1827 , d. 18 DEC 1876 .
(7) Mary Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1818 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 2 JUN 1820 Astoria, Queens Co., New York.
(7) Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 JUL 1819 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 25 AUG 1906 Stockbridge, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
m. 2 APR 1844 New York City, New York, Lucius Tuckerman, b. 19 MAR 1818 Chelsea, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 10 JUN 1890 Stockbridge, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesLUCIUS was a merchant in New York City, living at Manhattan in 1880. In 1879 he built a six story apartment house on Washington Square exclusively for bachelors, which became the home of notable artists such as Winslow Homer, Albert Ryder, Rockwell Kent, Edward Hopper, etc. He was an early benefactor of the Metropolitam Museum of Art and on the Social Register.
9 children: Lucius Carey, Alfred, Walter Cary, Laura Wolcott, Rupert, Emily, Bayard, Paul, Lucy.
(8) Lucius Carey Tuckerman8 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 AUG 1846 , d. 23 SEP 1849 .
(8) Alfred Tuckerman8 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 JAN 1848 , d. 24 MAY 1925 .
m. 10 DEC 1879 ,, New York, Clara I. Fargis, b. , d. 24 DEC 1924 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island.
(8) Walter Cary Tuckerman8 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 MAR 1849 ,, New York, d. 18 APR 1894 ,, Rhode Island.
m. 1 JUN 1875 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Florence Harding Fenno, b. 1848 ,, New York, d. 9 MAR 1887 .
(8) Laura Wolcott Tuckerman8 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 AUG 1850 ,, New York, d. 9 FEB 1914 .
m. 9 APR 1891 Washington, District of Columbia, James Lowndes, b. , d. .
(8) Rupert Tuckerman8 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 DEC 1851 , d. 23 NOV 1871 Newport, Newport Co., Rhode Island.
(8) Emily Tuckerman8 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 NOV 1853 ,, New York, d. .
(8) Bayard Tuckerman8 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 JUL 1855 New York City, New York, d. ABT 1920 .
NotesBAYARD graduated from Harvard in 1878; studied in Europe, and wrote on literary and historical subjects for periodicals. In 1880 he is described as an iron merchant, living with his parents at New York City. In 1898 he became lecturer on English Literature at Princeton University, a position he still held in 1903. He was the author of: "History of England Prose Fiction" (1882); "Life of General Lafayette with a Critical Estimate of his Character and Public Acts" (1889); and edited with an introduction, "Diary of Philip Hone" (1889); "Peter Stuyvesant" (1893); "William Jay and the Abolition of Slavery" (1893) and "Life of General Philip Schuyler" (1903). He was on the New York City Social Register.
m. 26 SEP 1882 Ipswich, Essex Co., Massachusetts, Anna Osgood Smith, b. 20 FEB 1862 New York City, New York, d. .
(8) Paul Tuckerman8 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 NOV 1856 ,, New York, d. .
NotesPAUL is described as an iron merchantat New York City in 1880. He built a large home at Tuxedo Park, New York, and was one of the original trustees of the Tuxedo Park Library.
m. 3 MAR 1886 Susan Minturn , b. 3 MAR 1865 , d. .
(8) Lucy Tuckerman8 (Elizabeth Wolcott "Eliza" Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 FEB 1858 Staten Island, Richmond Co., New York, d. 12 MAY 1904 .
m. 16 NOV 1882 Arthur George Sedgwick, b. 6 OCT 1844 New York City, New York, d. 14 JUL 1915 Pittsfield, Berkshire Co., Massachusetts.
(7) Oliver Wolcott "Wolcott" Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 21 FEB 1822 New York City, New York, d. 9 DEC 1908 .
NotesOLIVER dropped his first name at an early age, and called himself "Wolcott Gibbs". He entered Columbia College in 1837 and graduated in 1841. He then attended the College of Physicians and Surgeons there, qualifying as a medical doctor in 1845. He studied chemistry at the University of Berlin in the laboratories of Rose and Rammelsberg, and subsequently spent five months with Liebig in Giessen, returning to America in 1848. In that year he became professor of Chemistry at the Free Academy, which later became the University of the City of New York. In 1863 he became Rumsford Professor of Science at Harvard University which he held until his retirement in 1887. During the Civil War he was a member of the Executive Committee of the Sanitary Comission. In 1873 he was granted a LLD degree, and was appointed comissioner to the Vienna Exhibition. he was an honorary member of the German Chemical Society and the London Chemical Society, and one of the original members of the National Academy of Scienc. He is credited for introducing research into university requirements. In organic and analytical chemistry he discovered many new substances and developed new methods. His study of complex ammonia bases, double compounds, acids of metal, and metals of the platinum group, contributed markedly to the science of chemistry.
m. 1853 Josephine Mauran, b. , d. 16 FEB 1887 .
(7) Alfred Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 APR 1823 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 26 DEC 1868 Fort Leavenworth, Leavenworth Co., Kansas.
NotesALFRED graduated from the West Point Military Academy in 1846, and served in the Mexican War. As a Captain in the Civil War, he was taken prisoner by the Confederates and exchanged 27 August 1862. He was commissioned Colonel of the 130th New York Regiment of Volunteers on 6 September 1862. He reorganized his regiment as the 1st New York Dragoons in August 1863. He was appointed Brigadier General 19 Oct. 1864, and commanded a Brigade under Gen. Sheridan until 1865. He was present at the surrender of Gen. Lee. He mustered out of the army as a Major General 1 February 1866. He was then made a Major in the 7th U.S. Cavalry on 28 July 1866, serving under Gen. George Custer.
m. 27 DEC 1856 Richmond, Henrico Co., Virginia, Peggy Forshee Blair, b. JAN 1825 Richmond, Henrico Co., Virginia, d. 25 JUL 1908 .
2 children: Alfred Wolcott, John Blair "Blair".
(8) Alfred Wolcott Gibbs8 (Alfred Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 27 OCT 1856 Fort Filmore,, New Mexico, d. 19 MAY 1922 Wayne, Delaware Co., Pennsylvania.
NotesALFRED attended Rutgers College 1873-1874, and Stevens Institute of Technology 1874-1878, and entered railroad employment in 1879. He was a master mechanic and was Chief Mechanical Engineer on the Pennsylvania Railroad.
m. Marianne Everard Skelton, b. 1861 , d. .
(8) John Blair "Blair" Gibbs8 (Alfred Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 SEP 1858 Richmond, Henrico Co., Virginia, d. 12 JUN 1898 Guantanamo,, Cuba.
(7) Laura Wolcott Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 12 AUG 1827 , d. 1 DEC 1908 ,, Rhode Island.
m. 1853 Theophile Marie Oremieulx, b. 11 MAY 1815 ,, France, d. 3 JUL 1881 .
Spouse NotesTHEOPHILE came to America to fight in the Revolutionary War. He was an officer in the American Army, and an Assistant Professor at West Point Military Academy.
2 children: Laura Henriette, Leon F..
(8) Laura Henriette Oremieulx8 (Laura Wolcott Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1858 , d. 23 MAR 1945 New York City, New York.
m. 26 FEB 1884 James West Roosevelt, b. 2 JUL 1858 , d. 10 APR 1896 .
Spouse NotesJAMES. MD Columbia University 1880, Clinical Lecturer on Medicine 1886. He was a first cousin of President Theodore Roosevelt.
(8) Leon F. Oremieulx8 (Laura Wolcott Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. , d. .
(7) Francis Sarason Gibbs7 (Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 24 JUN 1831 Astoria, Queens Co., New York, d. 27 DEC 1882 New York City, New York.
NotesFRANCIS spent two years in Shanghai, China, as a resident agent for "Wolcott, Bates & Co.", a trading company. He returned to America and was in the grain exporting business in New York City. His firm failed when an English firm, which held the shipments on consignment, failed.
m. 6 JUN 1860 Eliza Gay Hosmer, b. 27 OCT 1836 New York City, New York, d. 24 NOV 1883 .
Spouse NotesEliza was frequently ill and spent time in California for her health . The children received some of their early education in Santa Barbara.
4 children: George, Annie Margaretta, Laura Wolcott, Lucius Tuckerman,
(8) George Gibbs8 (Francis Sarason Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 APR 1861 New York City, New York, d. 19 MAY 1940 .
NotesGEORGE was author of "The Gibbs Family of Rhode Island".
(8) Annie Margaretta Gibbs8 (Francis Sarason Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 DEC 1862 New York City, New York, d. 5 MAR 1922 .
(8) Laura Wolcott Gibbs8 (Francis Sarason Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 8 OCT 1865 New York City, New York, d. 1 MAY 1951 Milwaukee, Milwaukee Co., Wisconsin.
NotesLAURA spent much time in Milwaukee with her children. Later she moved to New York to live with her brother, George. Her grandson, Robert Nowell Miller, Jr., has a silver service presented to her on her 25th wedding anniversary.
m. 16 SEP 1891 Milwaukee, Milwaukee Co., Wisconsin, William Henry Miller, b. 15 OCT 1862 Milwaukee, Milwaukee Co., Wisconsin, d. 24 SEP 1923 Milwaukee, Milwaukee Co., Wisconsin.
(8) Lucius Tuckerman Gibbs8 (Francis Sarason Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 FEB 1869 New York City, New York, d. JAN 1909 .
NotesLUCIUS was a drama critic for the New Yorker magazine.
m. 7 APR 1901 Angelica Singleton Duer, b. 1878 , d. .
(8) Lucius Tuckerman Gibbs8 (Francis Sarason Gibbs7, Laura Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 FEB 1869 New York City, New York, d. JAN 1909 .
NotesLUCIUS was a drama critic for the New Yorker magazine.
m. Unknown , b. , d. .
(6) Elizabeth Stoughton Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 OCT 1795 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 2 JUL 1813 New York City, New York.
NotesELIZABETH died in the Gracie mansion of a hemmorhage on her wedding night.
m. 2 JUL 1813 New York City, New York, William Gracie, b. 28 NOV 1787 New York City, New York, d. .
Spouse NotesWILLIAM remarried but maintained contact with the Wolcott family after his wife's death
(6) Oliver Stoughton Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 18 JAN 1800 ,, New York, d. 23 MAY 1832 New York City, New York.
NotesOLIVER attended the U. S. Military Academy at West Point, and then was attached as Midshipman to the "Chesapeake". After he left the Navy he settled in Litchfield, Connecticut, and then moved to New Jersey. Later, his father lived with him in New York City. An 1833 court case, DuBois v. Hepburn, says that Oliver S. Wolcott, lessee of the plaintiff of land in Lycoming County, was born in Connecticut, but was domiciled in the state of Pennsylvania on 25 Sept. 1830. A painting of him by an unknown artist is in the Frederick Co., Maryland Historical Society.
m. 9 NOV 1820 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Jane Lowe Conard, b. 17 SEP 1803 , d. 1845 .
Spouse NotesJANE's portrait is in the Frederick Co. Historical Society, Frederick, Maryland.
3 children: Oliver, Oliver, Elizabeth Stoughton.
(7) Oliver Wolcott7 (Oliver Stoughton Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 NOV 1821 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 5 MAR 1823 .
(7) Oliver Wolcott7 (Oliver Stoughton Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 SEP 1823 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 22 MAY 1856 San Francisco, San Francisco Co., California.
NotesOLIVER received his MD at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York City. He lived in Argentina and died unmarried.
(7) Elizabeth Stoughton Wolcott7 (Oliver Stoughton Wolcott6, Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 31 JUL 1825 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 15 AUG 1825 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
(6) John Stoughton Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 DEC 1802 New York City, New York, d. 22 NOV 1843 New York City, New York.
NotesJohn S. Wolcott of CT was admitted to West Point 1 Sept. 1818, age 15 yrs 8 mo.

John practiced medicine at Litchfield, and later in New York City, where his father lived with him. Paintings of his father and grandfather Wolcott were presented by him to the Connecticut Senate in 1834. In 1925, miniature portraits of him and of his father, and a Latin text book inscribed with his name were presented to Peter Clark Wolcott for the Wolcott Society by Mrs. Olive K. Walden. Her aunt had been engaged to John.

April 8, 1844, Alexandria Gazette (Virginia): DIED: In Litchfield, Conn. Dr. JOHN STOUGHTON WALCOTT. His death was occasioned by the effects of arsenic and morphine, applied to the cavities of two hollow teeth, for the purpose of destroying the sensitiveness of their nerves.
(6) Henry Wolcott6 (Oliver Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 SEP 1805 ,, New York, d. 25 SEP 1805 ,, New York.
(5) Laura Wolcott5 (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 DEC 1761 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 23 JAN 1814 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
m. 6 OCT 1785 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut, William Moseley, b. ABT 1758 , d. .
Spouse NotesWILLIAM graduated from Yale College in 1777.
1 children: Charles.
(6) Charles Moseley6 (Laura Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 JUN 1786 , d. 29 MAR 1815 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
(5) Mariann Wolcott5 (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 16 FEB 1765 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 12 MAR 1805 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
NotesMariann's portrait, painted by Ralph Earl, is in the Litchfield, Connecticut, Museum.
m. 13 OCT 1789 ,, Connecticut, Chauncey Goodrich, b. 20 OCT 1759 Durham Township, Middlesex Co., Connecticut, d. 18 AUG 1815 Hartford, Hartford Co., Connecticut.
Spouse NotesCHAUNCEY graduated from Yale in 1759, and then studied law with Charles Chauncey. He moved to Hartford to practice law in 1781. In 1793 and 1794 he represented New Haven in the State Legislature. In 1794, he was elected to the U.S. Congress where he served until 1801. In 1802 he was chosen a member of the Council, the upper branch of the state legislature, where he served until he became a U.S. Senator in 1807. In 1813 he was elected Lt. Governor of the State of Connecticut, and Mayor of Hartford.
(5) Frederick Wolcott5 (Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 NOV 1767 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 28 MAY 1837 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
NotesFREDERICK graduated from Yale College in 1786, delivering the the salutatorian oration in Latin. He was Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas in 1793, and clerk of the Superior Court at Litchfield in 1798. In 1796 he was appointed Judge of Probate. He inherited his parents home on South Street at Litchfield in 1797. His black servant, Hebe Williams died at Litchfield in 1803. Frederick was elected as Representative to the Connecticut General Assembly in 1808, and in 1810 was elected to the State Senate, an office that he held until 1823. He was a partner with his brother, Oliver, in the development of the woolen mills at a place that became known as Wolcottville. He and his brother imported cattle from England and sheep from Spain, and worked to improve American breeds of cattle and sheep. During the Revolutionary War he provided public service in Connecticut. He and his wife sold 200 acres of land at Norwalk, Ohio in 1822, part of the estate of her first husband, Amos Cook.
m. 12 OCT 1800 Norwich, New London Co., Connecticut, Elizabeth "Betsey" Huntington, b. 8 NOV 1774 Norwich, New London Co., Connecticut, d. 2 APR 1812 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut.
6 children: Mariann Goodrich, Hannah Huntington, Joshua Huntington, Elizabeth Huntington, Frederick Henry "Fred", Laura Maria.
(6) Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 AUG 1801 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 26 APR 1864 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
m. 22 MAY 1827 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, Asa Whitehead, b. 26 MAY 1795 Livingston, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 2 JUN 1860 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
Spouse NotesASA was a leading Newark lawyer. He was a Delegate to Whig National Convention from New Jersey in 1839, and member, Committee on Permanent Organization; member of New Jersey state senate from Essex County, 1849-51. He raised and educated his nephew, John Whitehead, who became president of the New Jersey SAR and vice-president of the national SAR.
1 children: Frederick Wolcott.
(7) Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7 (Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 OCT 1846 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. .
NotesFREDERICK was a railroad clerk at Newark, New Jersey, in 1880, with Ada, Huntington, Aaron P., and Normee (?) Whitehead.
m. 13 AUG 1867 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, Ada Italia Locker, b. 5 OCT 1849 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. .
7 children: Frederick Wolcott, Asa, Ada Birdette, Archer Wolcott, Huntington Wolcott, Aaron Pennington, Genevieve Elise.
(8) Frederick Wolcott Whitehead8 (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 17 MAY 1868 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 24 JAN 1869 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
(8) Asa Whitehead8 (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 20 NOV 1869 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 15 AUG 1870 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
(8) Ada Birdette Whitehead8 (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 2 JAN 1872 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 26 AUG 1872 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
(8) Archer Wolcott Whitehead8 (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 JUN 1873 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 26 NOV 1873 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
(8) Huntington Wolcott Whitehead8 (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 JAN 1875 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
(8) Aaron Pennington Whitehead8 (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 23 JUL 1878 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. .
(8) Genevieve Elise Whitehead8 (Frederick Wolcott Whitehead7, Mariann Goodrich Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 MAY 1878 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 1952 Volusia,, Florida.
NotesGENEVIEVE was DAR member #148548.
m. Rial Newland Denison, b. 1885 Brooklyn, Kings Co., New York, d. .
(6) Hannah Huntington Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 14 JAN 1803 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 26 FEB 1838 Manayunk, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania.
m. 21 APR 1834 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, Frederick Freeman, b. 1 DEC 1799 Sandwich, Barnstable Co., Massachusetts, d. 12 SEP 1883 Sandwich, Barnstable Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesFREDERICK was rector of St. David's Church at Manayuck, Pennsylvania, and author of "A Plea for Africa"..
2 children: Huntington Wolcott, Hannah Huntington.
(7) Huntington Wolcott Freeman7 (Hannah Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 19 FEB 1835 New York City, New York, d. .
m. Clara Alexander, b. , d. .
(7) Hannah Huntington Freeman7 (Hannah Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 22 DEC 1837 Manayunk, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 30 JUN 1838 .
(6) Joshua Huntington Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 AUG 1804 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 6 JAN 1891 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesJOSHUA was a merchant. He entered the textile comission house, A. and A. Lawrence in Boston as an apprentice, and became a partner at age 26. When Abbott Lawrence was appointed Minister to England in 1849, Henry took over as managing partner of the firm. In 1857 J. Huntington Wolcott was a commercial merchant at 82 Milk St., Boston, residing at 48 Boylston, Boston. He was at Milton, Massachusetts, in 1860, with wife, Harriet, and son, Roger Wolcott, and a commercial merchant with A. A. Lawrence & Co. in Boston. He was Senior Partner when the firm dissolved in 1865. He was prominent in the development of New England manufacturing as president and director of many companies. He was involved in many charitable enterprises, and was state treasurer of the Sanitary Commission during the Civil War. He was a member of the Society of the Cincinnati, of which his grandfather was an original member. He was engaged to Elizabeth Flint of Nashville, Tennessee, but the engagement was broken. A marble bust of him is in the Newark Museum, and his papers are at the Massachusetts Historical Society.
m. 12 NOV 1844 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Cornelia Frothingham, b. 11 DEC 1824 Cambridge, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. 1 JUN 1850 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
2 children: Huntington Frothingham, Roger.
(7) Huntington Frothingham Wolcott7 (Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 4 FEB 1846 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 10 JUN 1865 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesHUNTINGTON was comissioned 23 Oct. 1864 as a 2nd Lt. in I Co., 2nd Regiment, Massachusetts Cavalry, during the Civil War. He served as an aide to his relative, Gen. Alfred Gibbs. At the end of the war, he participated in a Grand Review at Washington D. C., and two days later took ill with "camp fever". He returned to his father's home, where he died a week later from typhoid.
(7) Roger Wolcott7 (Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 JUL 1847 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 DEC 1900 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesROGER graduated from Harvard in 1870 and delivered the Class Oration. He received his LL.B. from Harvard Law School in 1874, and was a lawyer at Boston. He was a Member of the Boston Common City Council, 1877-79; the House of Representatives, 1882-84; Lieutenant-Governor of Massachusetts, 1892-95; became Governor upon the death of Governor Greenhalge in 1896 and was elected Governor, 1897-1898. He was the first President of the Republican Club of Massachusetts in 1891, a member of the Massachusetts Historical Society, Society of the Cincinnati and Loyal Legion and Society of Colonial Wars. He was overseer of Harvard University, 1885-1895, and Director and Trustee in many business and charitable organizations. In 1891 he established funds at Harvard in memory of Hunting Frothington Wolcott to benefit the Peabody Museum, and in memory of Joshua Huntington Wolcott to benefit the Harvard Library. A large bronze statue of him by Daniel Chester French graces the main lobby of the Massachusetts State House in Boston.

1910 Milton MA:
Edith P Wolcott F 57y
William P Wolcott M 30y
Cornelia F Wolcott F 25y
Oliver Wolcott M 19y
Dehlia A Ryan F 27y
Margaret M Queeney F 64y
Margaret M Walsh F 28y
Catharine Kenney F 27y
Ellen Carbac F 43y
John G Madden M 36y
William Brennan M 19y
Robert Crellin M 23y

Find A Grave memorial No. 10634892.
m. 2 SEP 1874 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Edith Prescott, b. 20 APR 1853 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 15 JUN 1934 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesEdith's great-great grandfather, Col. William Prescott, was Commander of American troops at the Battle of Bunker Hill. In 1899, she presented the Bunker Hill Monument to the town of Pepperell, placed on the Pepperell Common. Find A Grave memorial No. 45433906.
6 children: Huntington Frothingham, Roger, William Prescott "Prescott", Samuel Huntington, Cornelia Frothingham, Oliver.
(8) Huntington Frothingham Wolcott8 (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 NOV 1875 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 19 FEB 1877 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
(8) Roger Wolcott8 (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 JUL 1877 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 APR 1965 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesROGER graduated cum laude from Harvard College in 1899. He served in the Spanish-American War and was a Major in the Infantry Officers Reserve Corps, in charge of the draft for Massachusetts, during World War I. He was a member of the Harvard Board of Overseers. He was also a members of the Advisory Board of Massachusetts General Hospital. His wife, Claire, seperated from him in 1923, saying "he had allowed their palatial home to become so dillapidated and run down" that she was unable to stay there. She left Milton, Connecticut, returned to Boston.

Find A Grave memorial No. 78346099.
m. 7 JUN 1904 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Claire Morton Prince, b. 19 DEC 1885 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. .
(8) Roger Wolcott8 (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 25 JUL 1877 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 APR 1965 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesROGER graduated cum laude from Harvard College in 1899. He served in the Spanish-American War and was a Major in the Infantry Officers Reserve Corps, in charge of the draft for Massachusetts, during World War I. He was a member of the Harvard Board of Overseers. He was also a members of the Advisory Board of Massachusetts General Hospital. His wife, Claire, seperated from him in 1923, saying "he had allowed their palatial home to become so dillapidated and run down" that she was unable to stay there. She left Milton, Connecticut, returned to Boston.

Find A Grave memorial No. 78346099.
m. 21 JUN 1928 Baltimore, Baltimore Co., Maryland, Barbara Hinkley, b. 6 FEB 1889 Cambridge, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. 18 MAR 1958 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
(8) William Prescott "Prescott" Wolcott8 (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1 MAY 1880 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 JUN 1947 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesWILLIAM served as the American Red Cross representative at Base Hospital 18 in France during World War I. He was a member of the Wolcott Society living at Readville, Massachusetts, in 1914. He was a later a farmer at Milton, Massachusetts, and a noted sportsman and dog-show judge.

(8) Samuel Huntington Wolcott8 (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 9 NOV 1881 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 18 DEC 1964 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesSAMUEL was a member of the Executive Committee for Massachusetts of the American Protective League, and Captain in the First Cavalry Troop,Massachusetts State Guard, in 1919.

1918 Draft Registration:
Samuel Huntington Wolcott 36, b. 9 Nov 1881, Milton, Norfolk, Massachusetts, banker, Brown Bros. and Co., wife Hannah S. Wolcott, Milton, tall, medium build, brown eyes, black hair.

In 1930 he was at Milton, Massachusetts, with Hannah, Edith P., and Samuel, Robert S Wolcott.
m. 19 JUN 1907 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Hannah Stevenson, b. 25 JUN 1881 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 2 JUL 1976 .
(8) Cornelia Frothingham Wolcott8 (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 3 FEB 1885 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 21 JAN 1956 Milton, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
m. 18 APR 1911 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, Samuel Smith Drury, b. 18 OCT 1878 Bristol, Bristol Co., Rhode Island, d. 21 FEB 1938 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
Spouse NotesSAMUEL graduated from Harvard University in 1901, and became a missionary in the Phillipines. He was ordained in 1908 and became rector of St. Stephens Church in Boston. In 1910 he received a STB degree from Berkeley Divinity School and an honorary LHD degree from Trinity College. He received an honorary DD degree from Dartmouth College in 1917, an honorary DD degree from Williams College in 1921, and an honorary LittD degree from Princeton in 1922. He was Rector of St. Paul's School at Concord, New Hampshire, from 1911 to 1938. He was Director of the Harvard Alumni Association from 1919 to 1922, and an Overseer of Harvard from 1922 to 1928. He was the author of numerous books and articles. He and his son, Roger, wrote "In Pursuit of Pelicans", published in 1931. His biography, "Drury and St. Pauls:, written by his son, was published in 1964.
(8) Oliver Wolcott8 (Roger Wolcott7, Joshua Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 7 APR 1891 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 11 MAR 1967 South Hamilton, Essex Co., Massachusetts.
Notes OLIVER graduated from Harvard in 1913 and received his LLB in 1915. He was a Capt. in the U.S. Army Cavalry and served with the 28th Div. in France. In 1925, he was a Lt. Col. in the National Guard. He was legal counsel for the Old Colony Trust Co.
m. 2 DEC 1922 Ipswich, Essex Co., Massachusetts, Sybil Appleton, b. 28 DEC 1899 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts, d. 15 DEC 1973 Beverly, Essex Co., Massachusetts.
(6) Joshua Huntington Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 AUG 1804 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 6 JAN 1891 Boston, Suffolk Co., Massachusetts.
NotesJOSHUA was a merchant. He entered the textile comission house, A. and A. Lawrence in Boston as an apprentice, and became a partner at age 26. When Abbott Lawrence was appointed Minister to England in 1849, Henry took over as managing partner of the firm. In 1857 J. Huntington Wolcott was a commercial merchant at 82 Milk St., Boston, residing at 48 Boylston, Boston. He was at Milton, Massachusetts, in 1860, with wife, Harriet, and son, Roger Wolcott, and a commercial merchant with A. A. Lawrence & Co. in Boston. He was Senior Partner when the firm dissolved in 1865. He was prominent in the development of New England manufacturing as president and director of many companies. He was involved in many charitable enterprises, and was state treasurer of the Sanitary Commission during the Civil War. He was a member of the Society of the Cincinnati, of which his grandfather was an original member. He was engaged to Elizabeth Flint of Nashville, Tennessee, but the engagement was broken. A marble bust of him is in the Newark Museum, and his papers are at the Massachusetts Historical Society.
m. 12 NOV 1851 Harriet "Hattie" Frothingham, b. 1810 Cambridge, Middlesex Co., Massachusetts, d. .
(6) Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6 (Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 6 MAR 1806 Litchfield, Litchfield Co., Connecticut, d. 15 OCT 1875 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
m. 22 MAY 1827 Pompton Plains, Morris Co., New Jersey, John Peter Jackson, b. 8 JUN 1805 Acquackanonk,, New Jersey, d. 10 DEC 1861 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey.
Spouse NotesJOHN graduated from Princeton College in 1823. He was a lawyer, member of the New Jersey General Assembly 1831, Speaker of the House, Clerk of Essex Co. in 1839, Secretary of the New Jersey Railroad Company 1832, Director 1836-1861, Vice President and General Manager 1849.
11 children: Laura Wolcott, Mary Elizabeth, Julia Huntington, Frederick Wolcott, Joseph Cooke, John Peter, Hannah Wolcott, Huntington Wolcott, Charles Henry, Henry Griswold, Schuyler Brinckerhoff.
(7) Laura Wolcott Jackson7 (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 5 MAY 1828 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 9 JAN 1901 .
m. 26 JAN 1854 Charles Henry Parker, b. 1816 , d. .
Spouse NotesCHARLES graduated from Harvard University in 1835.
1 children: Harriet Wolcott.
(8) Harriet Wolcott Parker8 (Laura Wolcott Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 1867 , d. .
m. Edward Reynolds, b. 2 APR 1860 , d. 16 OCT 1936 .
(7) Mary Elizabeth Jackson7 (Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 NOV 1829 Newark, Essex Co., New Jersey, d. 7 MAY 1885 Germantown, Sussex Co., New Jersey.
m. 14 NOV 1849 Thomas Charlton Henry, b. 20 APR 1828 , d. 31 AUG 1890 .
5 children: Alexander, Charles Wolcott, James Bayard, John Jackson, Elizabeth Wolcott.
(8) Alexander Henry8 (Mary Elizabeth Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 29 DEC 1850 , d. .
m. 12 MAY 1875 Caroline Rosa Bayard, b. , d. .
(8) Charles Wolcott Henry8 (Mary Elizabeth Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 13 APR 1852 Philadelphia, Philadelphia Co., Pennsylvania, d. 23 NOV 1903 .
NotesCHARLES took over his father's lumber business, Henry, Bayard & Co., in 1872, and was active in the business until his death. He was a member of the Philadelphia Common Council in the 1870s and 1880s, served on the Fairmont Park Commission, and was a Trustee of the Chesnut Hill Academy. His uncle, Alexander Henry, was Mayor of Philadelphia 1858-1862. The Charles W. Henry Elementary School in Philadelphia was named for him.
m. 18 NOV 1885 Sarah Bonnell "Sallie" Houston, b. 1860 , d. 1938 .
(8) James Bayard Henry8 (Mary Elizabeth Jackson7, Elizabeth Huntington Wolcott6, Frederick Wolcott5, Oliver Wolcott4, Sarah Drake3, Job Drake2, Mary Wolcott1), b. 15 JAN 1857 , d. .
m. 18 OCT 1881 Mary E. McCorkle, b. , d. .
